functional_groups.description: Primary producers and primary consumers in the pelagic zone.  Includes organisms with high biomass production and low body size.  Important for energy transfer to higher trophic levels.  Vulnerable to ocean acidification and pollution.

Organisms that primarily consume algae and other plant matter on reefs.  Important for controlling algal growth and maintaining reef health.  Often have specialized feeding structures.  Vulnerable to habitat degradation and overgrazing.

Predatory organisms that occupy mid-level trophic positions on reefs.  Important for regulating populations of herbivores and other prey species.  Often have specialized hunting strategies and adaptations.  Vulnerable to habitat loss and overfishing.

Large predatory fish that occupy the top of the food web.  Important for maintaining ecosystem stability and regulating prey populations.  Often have long lifespans and slow reproductive rates.  Highly vulnerable to overfishing.
Predatory organisms not of primary commercial interest, contributing to ecosystem regulation through predation.
Herbivorous organisms not of primary commercial interest, contributing to ecosystem regulation through herbivory.

Primary producers and primary consumers in the pelagic zone.  Includes organisms with high biomass production and low body size.  Important for energy transfer to higher trophic levels.  Vulnerable to ocean acidification and pollution.

Organisms that primarily consume algae and other sessile or slow-moving primary producers in reef environments.  Important for controlling algal growth and maintaining reef health.  Often have specialized feeding structures.  Vulnerable to habitat degradation and overgrazing.

Predatory and opportunistic consumers found in reef ecosystems.  Play a key role in regulating prey populations and maintaining community structure.  Diverse body sizes and feeding strategies.  Vulnerable to overfishing and habitat loss.
Commercially important predatory fish.  High economic value and significant impact on fisheries.  Often have high predatory efficiency and are targeted for human consumption.
Organisms that primarily consume algae and other plant matter.  Important for controlling algal growth and maintaining ecosystem balance.  Can be vulnerable to habitat degradation and overgrazing.
Organisms that feed on dead organic matter.  Important for nutrient cycling and ecosystem cleanup.  Often have specialized adaptations for feeding on decaying material.

Primary producers and primary consumers in the pelagic zone.  Includes organisms with high biomass production and low body size.  Important for energy transfer to higher trophic levels.  Vulnerable to ocean acidification and pollution.

Organisms that primarily consume algae and other plant matter on reefs.  Important for controlling algal growth and maintaining reef health.  Often have specialized feeding structures.  Vulnerable to habitat degradation and overgrazing.

Predatory invertebrates and other reef-associated organisms with diverse feeding habits.  Play a crucial role in regulating prey populations and maintaining reef ecosystem stability.  Vulnerable to habitat loss and pollution.
Large predatory fish of high commercial value.  Important for regulating prey populations and maintaining ecosystem balance.  Highly vulnerable to overfishing.

Represents a diverse group of predators across various trophic levels.  Includes organisms with specialized hunting strategies and significant roles in regulating prey populations.  Vulnerable to habitat loss and overfishing.

Represents a diverse group of herbivores across various trophic levels.  Includes organisms that consume plant matter and play a key role in nutrient cycling and ecosystem structure.  Vulnerable to habitat loss and overgrazing.

Small to medium-sized pelagic fish that graze on phytoplankton and microzooplankton, playing a key role in energy transfer from primary producers to higher trophic levels. These species are typically fast-growing, short-lived, and exhibit high P/B and Q/B ratios. They are important prey for larger predators and contribute significantly to pelagic food web dynamics.

Benthic invertebrates that graze on macroalgae and detritus, contributing to benthic primary production recycling. These species are typically slow-growing, long-lived, and exhibit low to moderate P/B ratios. They play a critical role in maintaining benthic ecosystem structure and are vulnerable to habitat degradation and trawling.

Medium to large pelagic predators that occupy high trophic levels, feeding on smaller fish and invertebrates. These species have moderate to low P/B ratios, are long-lived, and exhibit high trophic transfer efficiency. They are key regulators of pelagic food webs and are highly vulnerable to overfishing.

Species of high commercial and cultural value that are targeted in fisheries. These species are typically large, long-lived, and have low to moderate P/B ratios. They are ecologically significant as apex or secondary consumers and are highly vulnerable to overfishing, requiring specific management attention.

Benthic invertebrates of high commercial and cultural importance, often harvested via trawling or hand collection. These species are typically long-lived, slow-growing, and have low P/B ratios. They are ecologically important for benthic community structure and are highly vulnerable to overexploitation and habitat destruction.

Generalized predatory organisms that occupy high trophic levels and play a key role in top-down control of prey populations. These species are typically generalist feeders with moderate to high Q/B ratios and are important for maintaining trophic balance in the ecosystem.

Generalized herbivorous organisms that consume primary producers and contribute to energy flow from autotrophs to higher trophic levels. These species are typically diverse in taxonomic composition but share similar feeding behavior, habitat use, and life history traits.

Small to medium-sized pelagic fish that graze on phytoplankton and microzooplankton, playing a key role in energy transfer from primary producers to higher trophic levels. These species are typically fast-growing, have high P/B and Q/B ratios, and are highly vulnerable to pelagic fishing. They serve as critical prey for larger predators and support commercial fisheries.

Benthic crustaceans that graze on macroalgae and detritus, contributing to nutrient cycling and habitat maintenance. They exhibit moderate growth rates and are important in benthic food webs. While not typically targeted commercially, they are ecologically significant and sensitive to habitat degradation.

Medium to large predatory fish that occupy high trophic levels in pelagic systems, feeding on smaller fish and invertebrates. These species are key components of commercial fisheries, have low P/B ratios, and are vulnerable to overfishing. Their removal can disrupt energy flow and cause trophic cascades.

Estuarine and coastal mullets that feed on detritus, algae, and microorganisms. They are ecologically important for nutrient cycling and serve as prey for larger predators. These species are generally less vulnerable to fishing than pelagic species but are sensitive to habitat loss and pollution.

Benthic predatory invertebrates that play a key role in controlling prey populations and maintaining benthic community structure. These species have low to moderate growth rates and are less vulnerable to fishing but sensitive to environmental changes. They contribute to energy transfer within benthic ecosystems.

Benthic herbivorous invertebrates that graze on algae and detritus, contributing to primary production utilization and habitat maintenance. These species are ecologically important but not targeted by fisheries. They are sensitive to habitat degradation and pollution.

A commercially and culturally significant seabird species that feeds on small pelagic fish and invertebrates. It occupies a high trophic level, has low reproductive rates, and is highly vulnerable to environmental changes and fisheries bycatch. Its presence is a key indicator of ecosystem health.

Small to medium-sized pelagic fish that graze on phytoplankton and microzooplankton, playing a key role in energy transfer from primary producers to higher trophic levels. They exhibit high P/B and Q/B ratios, are highly mobile, and are vulnerable to pelagic fishing. This group includes ecologically similar species with similar life history strategies and habitat use.

Benthic invertebrates that graze on macroalgae and detritus, contributing to nutrient cycling and habitat maintenance. They have moderate P/B ratios, are associated with rocky or sandy substrates, and are vulnerable to bottom trawling and habitat degradation. This group includes ecologically similar species with comparable feeding behavior and life history.

Medium to large pelagic predators that feed on smaller fish and invertebrates, occupying high trophic levels. They have lower P/B and Q/B ratios, exhibit long life spans, and are highly vulnerable to overfishing. This group includes ecologically similar species with similar foraging strategies and habitat use.

functional_groups.group_name: Commercially Important Pelagic Fish (Sardine and Anchovy)
functional_groups.description: Highly productive, small pelagic fish of significant commercial and cultural importance. These species are key components of marine food webs, exhibit high P/B and Q/B ratios, and are highly sensitive to environmental variability and overfishing. They are managed separately due to their economic and ecological significance.

Ecologically and economically significant decapod crustaceans that are harvested for food. They occupy benthic habitats, have moderate P/B ratios, and are vulnerable to overfishing and habitat loss. This group includes species with similar life history and ecological roles.

Generalized predatory organisms that occupy high trophic levels and play a key role in regulating prey populations. They exhibit low P/B ratios, are often long-lived, and are sensitive to fishing pressure. This group includes species with similar feeding behavior and ecological function, regardless of taxonomy.

Generalized herbivorous organisms that consume primary producers and contribute to energy transfer in benthic and pelagic systems. They have high P/B ratios and are important for nutrient cycling and habitat maintenance. This group includes species with similar feeding ecology and life history, regardless of taxonomic affiliation.
Herbivorous fish that feed on algae and detritus, occupying a lower trophic level. Includes commercially important species.
Small planktivorous fish that feed on zooplankton, occupying a middle trophic level. Includes anchovies and sardines.
Higher trophic level predators including fish and crustaceans that feed on other marine organisms.
Predatory species with undefined taxonomy but known to occupy a higher trophic level.
Herbivorous species with undefined taxonomy but known to occupy a lower trophic level.
Herbivorous fish species that feed on benthic vegetation and occupy near-bottom habitats.
Small pelagic fish that feed on plankton and occupy open water habitats, playing a key role in transferring energy from plankton to higher trophic levels.
Benthic predators of commercial importance, occupying substrate habitats and preying on other benthic organisms.
Benthic predators that are not of primary commercial interest but still play important ecological roles as top consumers in benthic ecosystems.
A bird species that serves as a top predator, primarily feeding on fish and occupying coastal or nearshore habitats.
Herbivorous fish feeding on algae and detritus, occupying benthic or shallow water habitats.
Small pelagic fish feeding on plankton, occupying open water habitats.
Predatory species including penguins and spiny lobsters, occupying both pelagic and benthic habitats.
Herbivorous species with ecological roles similar to other herbivores but not specifically identified.
Predatory species with ecological roles similar to other predators but not specifically identified.
Top marine predator endemic to the Galápagos, piscivorous, pelagic‑coastal forager; long‑lived, low P/B, high vulnerability to tourism and by‑catch.
Fast‑moving, high‑trophic level pelagic fish; opportunistic piscivore with high Q/B, moderate P/B; targeted by sport and commercial fisheries, vulnerable to over‑exploitation.
Medium‑sized, near‑shore demersal fishes that graze on algae and detritus; moderate P/B and Q/B; important for local fisheries and ecosystem nutrient recycling.

functional_groups.group_name: Small Pelagic Forage Fish – Commercial Planktivores
functional_groups.description: High‑reproduction, low‑biomass pelagic fishes feeding on zooplankton and phytoplankton; very high P/B and Q/B; primary prey for higher trophic levels and heavily harvested for bait and human consumption.

Medium‑sized benthic or demersal fishes that prey on invertebrates and smaller fishes; intermediate P/B and Q/B; not targeted by major fisheries, serving as important energy conduits to higher predators.

functional_groups.group_name: Commercial Benthic Crustacean Harvesters – Spiny and Slipper Lobsters
functional_groups.description: Large, long‑lived benthic crustaceans occupying reef and rocky habitats; low P/B, moderate Q/B; high commercial value and sensitive to habitat degradation and over‑fishing.
Generalist herbivores and planktivores not represented by specific species; low to moderate P/B, low Q/B; contribute to primary production control and energy flow to higher trophic levels.

Small-bodied, high turnover species that feed on zooplankton in the open water column. They have high production/biomass (P/B) and consumption/biomass (Q/B) ratios, serve as key energy conduits from primary production to higher trophic levels, and are heavily targeted by commercial fisheries.

Medium-sized, near‑shore benthic/epipelagic omnivores that graze on detritus, algae, and benthic microfauna. They exhibit moderate P/B ratios, recycle nutrients, and support artisanal and small‑scale fisheries.

Large, long‑lived crustacean predators and scavengers that inhabit rocky or coral reef habitats. They have low P/B, high trophic position, and are of high market value for both export and local consumption.

Apex or high‑level open‑water predators that primarily consume forage fish. They display low P/B, high Q/B, exert strong top‑down control, and are vulnerable to by‑catch and habitat changes but are not directly targeted by fisheries.

Flightless seabird that forages on small pelagic fish and squid near the coast. Occupies a top‑predator niche with low reproductive rates, making it sensitive to environmental variability and ecosystem shifts.

Small‑to‑medium benthic predators that feed on invertebrates and other fish on or near the seabed. They have moderate P/B and Q/B ratios, contribute to benthic energy flow, and are not of commercial importance.

Benthic herbivores and detritivores that consume macroalgae, seagrass, and organic sediments. They exhibit high P/B, play a crucial role in primary production conversion and nutrient cycling, and are not targeted by fisheries.

Small pelagic forage fishes that feed on zooplankton and phytoplankton, exhibiting high production‑to‑biomass (P/B) and consumption‑to‑biomass (Q/B) ratios. They occupy the upper water column, function as primary consumers, and support higher trophic levels. These species are heavily targeted by commercial fisheries.

Medium‑sized, benthopelagic mullet species that are omnivorous/detritivorous, feeding on algae, detritus, and small invertebrates. They have moderate P/B ratios, relatively fast turnover, and are important for coastal commercial fisheries.

Large reef‑associated spiny lobsters that are benthic predators and scavengers. They are long‑lived, have low P/B but high economic value, and are targeted by artisanal and industrial lobster fisheries.

Demersal benthic crustacean (slipper lobster) with a life history similar to spiny lobsters but occupying softer substrates. It has low P/B, high market price, and is harvested in specialized fisheries.
Fast‑growing, high‑trophic‑level pelagic predator that preys on smaller fish and cephalopods. It exhibits high Q/B, low commercial importance, and is sensitive to over‑fishing and habitat changes.

Demersal mid‑trophic fishes that feed on benthic invertebrates and small fishes. They have moderate Q/B ratios, play a key role in energy transfer from benthic primary consumers to higher predators, and are not primary commercial targets.

Top marine avian predator that feeds on small fish and squid. It is highly sensitive to environmental variability and fisheries pressure, and holds cultural and tourism value rather than commercial fishery importance.

Aggregated functional group representing various pelagic and demersal predators not listed individually. These organisms occupy mid‑to‑high trophic levels, have moderate to high Q/B ratios, and are important for maintaining food‑web stability.

Broad functional group of herbivorous and detritivorous fishes that graze on macroalgae, seagrass, and benthic microalgae. They have high P/B ratios, act as primary consumers, and support energy flow to higher trophic levels.

Medium-sized pelagic predator occupying the mid-trophic level, feeding on smaller fish and cephalopods. It is a key species for commercial fisheries, has a relatively high production-to-biomass (P/B) ratio, and is vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation.

Benthic detritivore of small to medium size that feeds on algae and detritus in nearshore habitats. It has a high production rate, is an important local fishery resource, and is moderately vulnerable to fishing pressure.

Benthic detritivore of small to medium size that feeds on algae and detritus in nearshore habitats. It has a high production rate, is an important local fishery resource, and is moderately vulnerable to fishing pressure.

Benthic detritivore of small to medium size that feeds on algae and detritus in nearshore habitats. It has a high production rate, is an important local fishery resource, and is moderately vulnerable to fishing pressure.

Small pelagic forage fish family with high production-to-biomass ratios. These species feed on plankton, are a critical link in the food web, and are heavily targeted by commercial fisheries, making them highly vulnerable to overexploitation.
Small pelagic anchovy that feeds on plankton. It has a high production rate, is an important commercial species, and is vulnerable to high fishing pressure.
Small pelagic forage fish that feeds on plankton. It has a high production-to-biomass ratio, is a key species for commercial fisheries, and is vulnerable to overfishing.

Small pelagic forage fish family with high production rates and high Q/B ratios. These species feed on plankton, are essential for commercial fisheries, and are highly susceptible to overexploitation.
Small pelagic fish that feeds on plankton. It has a high production rate, is an important commercial species, and is moderately vulnerable to fishing pressure.
Small pelagic fish that feeds on plankton. It has a high production rate, is an important commercial species, and is moderately vulnerable to fishing pressure.
Small pelagic fish that feeds on plankton. It has a high production rate, is an important commercial species, and is moderately vulnerable to fishing pressure.
Reef-associated benthic predator of large size that feeds on mollusks and crustaceans. It is a high-value commercial species, highly vulnerable to habitat degradation and overfishing.
Reef-associated benthic predator of large size that feeds on mollusks and crustaceans. It is a high-value commercial species, highly vulnerable to habitat degradation and overfishing.
Reef-associated herbivore that feeds on algae. It is harvested for roe, has a high production rate, and is vulnerable to overharvest and habitat loss.

Marine seabird that acts as a top predator, feeding on fish and cephalopods. It is not harvested commercially but plays a key role in ecosystem structure and is vulnerable to climate change and pollution.

General group of predatory species across trophic levels, including top predators and mesopredators. These species regulate prey populations, facilitate energy transfer, and are often sensitive to changes in prey availability and fishing pressure.
General group of herbivorous species such as sea urchins and herbivorous fish. They control primary production, influence habitat structure, and are important for nutrient cycling and energy flow.
Pelagic piscivorous predator, medium-sized, high commercial value, vulnerable to overfishing, key top predator in coastal ecosystems.
Nearshore benthic filter feeder, small to medium, important commercial species, susceptible to habitat degradation and overfishing.
Nearshore filter feeder, small to medium, widely fished, high productivity, vulnerable to overfishing and habitat loss.
Nearshore filter feeder, small to medium, commercial importance, susceptible to overfishing and environmental changes.
Small pelagic filter feeders, high productivity, major commercial species, vulnerable to overfishing and climate change.
Small pelagic filter feeder, high commercial value, important forage species, vulnerable to overfishing.
Small pelagic filter feeder, high productivity, major commercial species, subject to stock fluctuations.
Small pelagic filter feeders, high commercial value, key forage species, vulnerable to overfishing and environmental changes.
Small pelagic filter feeder, commercial importance, important forage species, vulnerable to overfishing.
Benthic predator, medium-large, high commercial value, vulnerable to overfishing and habitat loss.
Benthic predator, medium-large, high commercial value, vulnerable to overfishing and habitat loss.
Marine predators, including large piscivorous birds and fish, key top‑down control, high trophic level, important for ecosystem stability.
Benthic herbivores/detritivores, important for nutrient cycling and habitat maintenance.
Small pelagic filter feeders that contribute to primary production and serve as forage for higher trophic levels.

Marine bird predator that feeds on fish and invertebrates in pelagic and nearshore waters. High trophic level, important for nutrient cycling and as a bioindicator of marine ecosystem health. Vulnerable to bycatch and habitat loss.

Pelagic predatory fish (pike mackerel) that occupies mid‑to‑upper trophic levels. Key species in commercial fisheries, high growth rates, and important for controlling forage fish populations. Susceptible to overfishing and habitat degradation.

Benthic herbivorous mullet that grazes on algae and detritus on sandy and muddy substrates. Moderate body size, high reproductive output, and important for benthic‑pelagic coupling. Vulnerable to habitat loss and overfishing.

Benthic herbivorous mullet that feeds on benthic algae and detritus. Plays a key role in nutrient recycling and sediment stabilization. High production and commercial value make it vulnerable to overfishing.

Benthic herbivorous mullet that consumes benthic algae and detritus. Important for maintaining benthic habitat quality and providing food for higher trophic levels. Susceptible to overfishing and habitat degradation.

Small pelagic forage fish family (anchovies) that exhibit high production and rapid turnover. Serve as a critical food source for larger predators and are heavily fished for both direct consumption and fishmeal. Vulnerable to overfishing and environmental change.

Small pelagic forage fish that feeds on plankton and serves as a key prey species for larger fish and marine mammals. High reproductive rates and commercial importance make it susceptible to overfishing.

Small pelagic forage fish (Pacific sardine) that has high production and is a major commercial species. Plays a pivotal role in transferring energy from plankton to higher trophic levels. Vulnerable to overfishing and climate‑driven shifts in plankton communities.

Small pelagic forage fish family (herrings) that exhibit high production and rapid growth. Serve as a key prey base for larger fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. Commercially important and vulnerable to overfishing and habitat changes.

Small pelagic forage fish (silver sardine) that feeds on plankton and is an important prey species for larger fish and marine mammals. High production and commercial value make it susceptible to overfishing.

Benthic carnivorous fish that preys on invertebrates and smaller fish. Moderate body size, important for controlling benthic invertebrate populations, and commercially valuable. Vulnerable to bottom trawling and habitat degradation.

Benthic carnivorous fish that feeds on benthic invertebrates. Plays a role in structuring benthic communities and is commercially harvested. Susceptible to overfishing and bottom‑contact fishing gear.
Benthic invertebrate predator (spiny lobster) that occupies reef and rocky habitats. High commercial value, important for reef food webs, and vulnerable to overfishing and habitat loss.

Benthic invertebrate predator (spiny lobster) that inhabits reef and rocky substrates. Key species for reef ecosystems and heavily fished for its high market value. Vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation.

Benthic invertebrate herbivore (sea urchin) that grazes on macroalgae and contributes to reef maintenance. Commercially harvested for food and ornamental purposes. Vulnerable to overgrazing and fishing pressure.

Generic predator group representing non‑commercial species that occupy higher trophic levels, including various fish and invertebrates. These organisms regulate prey populations and maintain food web stability.

Generic herbivore group representing non‑commercial species that feed on primary producers, such as algae and detritus. These organisms are essential for primary production, nutrient cycling, and habitat structuring.

Large predatory fish and birds that occupy the top trophic level in the ecosystem. These species primarily feed on smaller fish, squid, and other marine animals. They play a crucial role in regulating prey populations and maintaining ecosystem balance.
Species that primarily feed on algae, detritus, or small invertebrates. These fish are important for nutrient cycling and maintaining the balance of benthic habitats.
Small, schooling fish that are key prey species for larger predators. They occupy the mid-trophic level and are important in energy transfer from zooplankton to higher trophic levels.
Small, schooling fish of high commercial value. These species are crucial for fisheries and ecosystem functioning, often serving as a link between primary producers and higher trophic levels.
Predatory fish that primarily inhabit benthic habitats. These species feed on invertebrates and smaller fish, playing a role in controlling benthic prey populations.
Lobsters and similar species that are important both ecologically and commercially. These species are key benthic predators and contribute to the structure of benthic communities.
A grouping of predatory species that share similar ecological roles but are not otherwise taxonomically close. These predators feed on a variety of prey and help regulate ecosystem processes.

A grouping of herbivorous species that share similar ecological roles but are not otherwise taxonomically close. These species feed on algae and other primary producers, contributing to nutrient cycling.
Top predators feeding on fish, squid, and other marine animals. Includes commercially important species.
Herbivores feeding on algae and detritus, including commercially important mullet species.
Schooling fish feeding on plankton, crucial in the food web as prey for larger predators.
Predators feeding on smaller fish and invertebrates, balancing the ecosystem.
Benthic predators feeding on small invertebrates and detritus, including commercially important lobster species.
Catch-all group for predatory species not assigned to other groups, ensuring all taxa are accounted for.
Catch-all group for herbivorous species not assigned to other groups, ensuring all taxa are included.
Herbivorous fish species that primarily feed on algae and detritus, playing a key role in nutrient cycling and benthic-pelagic coupling.
Small pelagic fish species that are primarily planktivorous or feed on small invertebrates, serving as a critical link between zooplankton and higher trophic levels.
Predatory fish species that primarily feed on other fish or larger invertebrates, occupying higher trophic levels and playing a key role in regulating prey populations.
Benthic crustacean species that are primarily herbivorous or detritivorous, contributing to benthic habitat structure and nutrient cycling.
A group of unspecified predatory species that likely occupy higher trophic levels and play a role in regulating prey populations.
A group of unspecified herbivorous species that likely feed on algae or detritus, contributing to nutrient cycling and benthic-pelagic coupling.
An endemic and culturally significant species that feeds on fish and squid, playing a unique role in the ecosystem.

Large, long-lived benthic invertebrates occupying rocky and coral reef habitats. These are apex predators or mesopredators with high commercial value, slow growth, low P/B ratios, and high vulnerability to fishing. They play key roles in benthic community regulation and are culturally significant.

Medium-sized, euryhaline fish inhabiting coastal and estuarine environments, often feeding on detritus and benthic microalgae. They exhibit moderate P/B and Q/B ratios, serve as mid-trophic level consumers, and link benthic production to higher predators. Includes both endemic and widespread species.

functional_groups.group_name: Small pelagic forage fish (clupeids and engraulids)
functional_groups.description: Short-lived, schooling fish occupying mid to upper trophic levels in the pelagic zone. High P/B and Q/B ratios indicate rapid turnover and high consumption. Key energy conduits from plankton to piscivores. Includes both taxonomically defined species and family-level groupings due to ecological similarity.

Large, fast-swimming predatory fish occupying high trophic levels in the pelagic ecosystem. Feed on smaller fish and invertebrates, with moderate P/B ratios and high Q/B ratios. Play a top-down regulatory role and are vulnerable to overfishing due to life history traits.

Small to medium-sized reef- or rock-associated fish with carnivorous diets, feeding on invertebrates and small fish. Low to moderate P/B ratios, specialized habitat use, and limited distribution (e.g., Galápagos endemics). Contribute to benthic-pelagic coupling.

Endemic penguin species with high cultural and conservation significance. Occupies a unique apex predator niche in the marine ecosystem, feeding on small pelagics. Low P/B ratio due to K-selected life history, and highly vulnerable to environmental change and food web shifts.

Shellfish and crustaceans with cryptic lifestyles on soft or hard substrates. Includes non-commercial slipper lobsters. Moderate to low P/B ratios, contribute to benthic community structure and serve as prey for larger predators. Low fishing pressure but sensitive to habitat degradation.

Generalized predatory organisms representing unclassified or aggregated species with carnivorous feeding habits across various habitats. Used to account for missing trophic pathways and ensure energy flow completeness. Assumed to have moderate turnover and broad diet.

Generalized herbivorous organisms, likely including fish or invertebrates that graze on macroalgae or seagrass. Represent key primary consumers in benthic food webs, especially in reef and coastal systems. Important for controlling algal growth and maintaining habitat health.

Large, slow-growing, benthic invertebrates with high commercial value. These are nocturnal predators inhabiting rocky and coral reefs, playing key roles in benthic community regulation. They have low P/B and Q/B ratios, are long-lived, and are highly vulnerable to overfishing due to life history traits and market demand.

Mid-to-upper trophic level predatory fish occupying offshore and coastal pelagic zones. These species are fast-swimming, have moderate to high P/B and Q/B ratios, and feed on small schooling fish. They serve as key energy conduits between lower trophic levels and top predators, with some vulnerability to fisheries.

functional_groups.group_name: Small pelagic forage fish (clupeids and engraulids)
functional_groups.description: Small, short-lived, schooling fish in the pelagic zone with high P/B and Q/B ratios. These species are primary consumers or low-level carnivores, forming the base of pelagic food webs. They are critical for energy transfer to higher trophic levels and are vulnerable to environmental variability and fisheries.

Euryhaline, benthopelagic fish with omnivorous feeding habits, often consuming detritus and microalgae. They occupy estuarine, coastal, and reef-associated habitats, linking benthic and pelagic systems. Moderate P/B and Q/B ratios, with some species of local commercial interest but generally less targeted.

Small to medium-sized benthic-feeding fish with specialized diets on invertebrates. These species occupy reef and soft-bottom habitats, have moderate turnover rates, and contribute to benthic community regulation. They are ecologically important but not typically targeted by fisheries.

Flightless seabird with high cultural and conservation significance, occupying a unique apex predator niche in nearshore pelagic systems. Feeds on small fish and invertebrates, has low reproductive rate and P/B ratio, and is highly vulnerable to environmental change and human impacts.

Benthic, reef-associated crustaceans with cryptic behavior and moderate mobility. These species occupy a scavenger/predator niche, have low P/B ratios, and play roles in nutrient cycling. Not typically targeted by fisheries, thus differing from commercial lobsters in management relevance.

Generalized predatory species across trophic levels that are not individually resolved. Includes small to medium-sized predators with varied habitat use, contributing to top-down control. Aggregated due to limited data, with assumed moderate P/B and Q/B ratios.

Primary consumers including fish and invertebrates that graze on macroalgae and microphytobenthos. Key for controlling algal growth and maintaining reef resilience. Occupy benthic and reef-associated habitats with moderate turnover rates. Aggregated due to taxonomic uncertainty and data limitations.

Small to medium-sized pelagic fish that feed primarily on plankton and serve as key prey for higher trophic levels. These species occupy mid-trophic levels, have high P/B and Q/B ratios, and are important in transferring energy from primary producers and zooplankton to piscivores. Include members of Clupeidae and Engraulidae with similar life history strategies.

Euryhaline, benthopelagic fish that feed on detritus, microalgae, and organic matter in coastal and estuarine environments. They play a key role in nutrient cycling and energy transfer from benthic primary production to higher trophic levels. Characterized by moderate P/B and low trophic level, these species are ecologically important but not major commercial targets in most contexts.

Medium to large predatory fish associated with rocky reefs and coastal habitats. These species occupy high trophic positions, have lower P/B ratios, and exert top-down control on forage fish and invertebrate populations. They are long-lived with slower life histories and are vulnerable to overfishing.

Endemic, flightless seabird that functions as a top predator in the nearshore marine ecosystem. Occupies a unique ecological niche with high foraging demands and sensitivity to environmental variability. Represents a species of high conservation and cultural importance with no close functional equivalents.

Benthic crustaceans that are nocturnal omnivores and scavengers, playing important roles in benthic community dynamics and nutrient cycling. They have moderate to low P/B ratios, are long-lived, and are highly vulnerable to fishing pressure. Represent key commercial invertebrate resources.

Generalized predatory species that consume fish, crustaceans, and other invertebrates. Occupy high trophic levels and contribute to top-down regulation. Group includes non-specified predators with life history and metabolic rates comparable to observed piscivores, used to represent missing or aggregated taxa in data-limited contexts.

Herbivorous organisms, including fish and invertebrates, that graze on macroalgae and primary producers in coastal and reef environments. Play a critical role in controlling algal growth and maintaining habitat structure. Characterized by high P/B ratios and strong interactions with benthic primary production.

High trophic level, apex predators in the pelagic zone; characterized by high mobility, high Q/B and P/B ratios, and significant commercial importance. They occupy top positions in marine food webs and are highly vulnerable to overfishing.

functional_groups.group_name: Medium Pelagic Predators (Scombrids and Related Species)
functional_groups.description: Mid-trophic level pelagic predators with moderate mobility and high metabolic rates. They play key roles in energy transfer from mesozooplankton to higher trophic levels and are ecologically and commercially important.

functional_groups.group_name: Small Pelagic Fish (Sardines, Anchovies, and Relatives)
functional_groups.description: Low to mid-trophic level, schooling fish that feed on zooplankton and serve as critical energy transfer agents between primary consumers and higher predators. High P/B ratios and significant commercial value.

Mid to high trophic level organisms inhabiting mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones; characterized by low metabolic rates, low P/B ratios, and specialized feeding strategies. Include key components of deep-sea food webs and are vulnerable to deep-sea fishing.

functional_groups.group_name: Large Pelagic Filter Feeders and Grazers
functional_groups.description: High biomass, low trophic level organisms that consume plankton and detritus; play a key role in nutrient cycling and energy transfer. Include large filter feeders and herbivorous species with high P/B ratios.

Mid-trophic level, drifting organisms that form the base of the pelagic food web. Include large copepods, euphausiids, and other zooplankton with high P/B ratios and significant roles in energy transfer.
Autotrophic organisms forming the base of marine food webs. Include phytoplankton and cyanobacteria with high P/B ratios, critical for primary production and carbon fixation.
Benthic organisms that feed on detritus, algae, and microorganisms; play key roles in nutrient recycling and benthic-pelagic coupling. Include crustaceans, mollusks, and other benthic invertebrates.

Highly mobile, predatory invertebrates with high Q/B ratios and significant ecological roles as mid- to high-trophic level consumers. Include squids, cuttlefish, and octopuses with diverse life histories and habitat use.

Low to mid-trophic level, reef-associated or coastal fish with diverse feeding strategies (herbivory, omnivory, predation). Important for reef ecosystem function and often targeted by small-scale fisheries.
Heterotrophic protists and small metazoans that consume bacteria and other microplankton; play a critical role in microbial loop and energy transfer in oligotrophic systems.
Taxa of significant commercial, cultural, or economic value that are not grouped by ecological function. These are retained as distinct entities for management and policy relevance.

High trophic level, epipelagic predators with high mobility and energy demands. These species are apex predators in open ocean food webs, playing key roles in energy transfer from mid-trophic levels to higher trophic levels. They exhibit high Q/B and P/B ratios, indicating rapid growth and high metabolic rates. Many are commercially important and vulnerable to overfishing.

functional_groups.group_name: Medium Pelagic Predators (Scombrids and Related Species)
functional_groups.description: Mid-trophic level, pelagic predators with moderate body size and high mobility. They occupy key positions in energy transfer from mesozooplankton and small fish to larger predators. These species have moderate P/B and Q/B ratios and are important in both ecological and commercial contexts.

Predators inhabiting mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones, often with specialized feeding strategies and low metabolic rates. They play critical roles in vertical energy transfer and carbon export. Many have low P/B ratios and are less studied but ecologically significant.

Organisms that consume planktonic primary producers and small zooplankton, playing a key role in energy transfer from primary producers to higher trophic levels. They include both large filter feeders and small grazers with high P/B ratios, contributing significantly to nutrient cycling.

Benthic organisms that feed on detritus, meiofauna, and small invertebrates. They play critical roles in benthic-pelagic coupling and nutrient recycling. Many have low P/B ratios and are sensitive to habitat disturbance.

Fish species associated with coral reefs and rocky substrates, exhibiting diverse feeding strategies including herbivory, omnivory, and predation. They contribute to reef resilience, nutrient cycling, and trophic complexity. Many are ecologically important but not always commercially targeted.

Highly mobile, short-lived cephalopods with high metabolic rates and significant roles in energy transfer. They are both predators and prey, contributing to trophic dynamics in pelagic and benthic systems. Many are ecologically important but underrepresented in fisheries data.

Autotrophic organisms forming the base of marine food webs. They include picophytoplankton, nanophytoplankton, and larger phytoplankton groups, responsible for primary production and carbon fixation. Key contributors to energy input in pelagic ecosystems.

Microbial communities including bacterioplankton and heterotrophic nano- and picozooplankton. They play essential roles in decomposition, nutrient regeneration, and carbon cycling. High turnover rates and low biomass make them critical for ecosystem metabolism.

Species with significant economic, cultural, or food security value. These taxa are often targeted by industrial or artisanal fisheries and are key indicators of ecosystem health and sustainability. They are separated from ecologically similar but non-commercial taxa for management purposes.

High trophic level, epipelagic predators with high mobility, feeding on mid-sized fish and squid. Key energy transfer agents in open ocean food webs. Highly vulnerable to overfishing due to high commercial value and slow life history traits.

functional_groups.group_name: Medium Pelagic Predators (Scombrids and Related Species)
functional_groups.description: Mid-trophic level, pelagic predators with moderate mobility, feeding on small fish and crustaceans. Important in energy transfer between lower trophic levels and large predators. Moderate vulnerability to fishing pressure.

Low to mid-trophic level, schooling fish that feed on zooplankton and microplankton. Key intermediaries in pelagic food webs, transferring energy from plankton to higher trophic levels. Highly sensitive to environmental variability and overfishing.

Mid to high trophic level, vertically migrating or deep-dwelling predators with low metabolic rates and slow growth. Play critical roles in deep-ocean energy transfer and carbon cycling. Vulnerable to deep-sea fishing and climate change.

functional_groups.group_name: Large Pelagic Filter Feeders (Rays and Sharks)
functional_groups.description: High trophic level, pelagic filter feeders with low feeding rates but high biomass turnover. Play key roles in regulating plankton populations and nutrient cycling. Highly vulnerable to bycatch and overfishing.

Mid-trophic level, mobile zooplankton that graze on phytoplankton and microzooplankton. Critical link in pelagic food webs, with high P/B and Q/B ratios. Sensitive to environmental change and overfishing of predators.

Low trophic level, heterotrophic microorganisms including ciliates, rotifers, and small cladocerans. High metabolic rates and rapid turnover. Key in microbial loop and nutrient recycling. Highly sensitive to environmental perturbations.

Autotrophic organisms forming the base of marine food webs. Include diatoms, dinoflagellates, and cyanobacteria. Vary in size and growth strategy, but collectively drive primary production and carbon fixation. Highly sensitive to nutrient availability and climate change.

Heterotrophic, picoplanktonic bacteria and archaea that decompose organic matter and recycle nutrients. High P/B ratios and central to microbial loop. Critical for carbon and nutrient cycling in oligotrophic systems.

Benthic and reef-associated species with diverse feeding strategies (herbivory, omnivory, predation). Include reef fish, crustaceans, and mollusks. Play key roles in reef ecosystem structure and resilience. Vulnerable to habitat degradation and overfishing.

Mid to high trophic level, short-lived, highly mobile cephalopods with high metabolic rates. Key predators and prey in pelagic and mesopelagic zones. Ecologically important but not targeted commercially. High P/B and Q/B ratios.

Species of high commercial or cultural value that are not apex predators. Include small pelagic fish, crustaceans, and some reef species. Critical for fisheries and food security, but often overexploited.

High-value, high-trophic level pelagic predators targeted by industrial fisheries. Include tunas, billfishes, and large sharks. Central to fisheries management and conservation policy due to overfishing risks.

Cartilaginous fish including sharks and rays, often apex predators with unique life history strategies.
Non-predatory gelatinous organisms that influence water clarity and ecosystem dynamics.
Decapods and other crustaceans playing roles as both predators and prey in marine ecosystems.
Diverse group of invertebrates with varied ecological roles, including some with cultural significance.
Large, highly migratory predators at the top of the pelagic food web, including billfishes and tuna.
Fish species that are integral to coral reef ecosystems, including herbivores and carnivores.

Intelligent marine molluscs that are important both as predators and prey in marine ecosystems.
A diverse group of organisms living on the seafloor, playing crucial roles in nutrient cycling and ecosystem structure.
Species of significant economic or cultural value that require special management attention.

Includes phytoplankton (diatoms, dinoflagellates, cyanobacteria) and other photosynthetic organisms.  Forms the base of the pelagic food web, responsible for primary production and oxygen generation.  Characterized by high P/B ratios.
Consumes phytoplankton and other primary producers.  Important for transferring energy from primary producers to higher trophic levels.  Often small and abundant.
Predators of zooplankton and other small herbivores.  Important for regulating zooplankton populations and transferring energy to larger predators.  Often have high Q/B ratios.

Large predators at the top of the pelagic food web.  Important for regulating populations of smaller predators and maintaining ecosystem stability.  Often have high Q/B ratios and long life histories.
Organisms that live on the seafloor and feed on detritus, dead organisms, or other organic matter.  Important for nutrient cycling and waste removal.  Diverse body sizes and feeding strategies.
Fish species that are harvested for human consumption.  Often have high economic value and are subject to fisheries management.  Represent a significant component of marine ecosystems.
Invertebrate species that are harvested for human consumption or other commercial purposes.  Important for fisheries and aquaculture.  Often have high economic value.

Includes bacteria, archaea, protists (ciliates, sarcodines), and other microorganisms.  Plays a critical role in nutrient cycling and energy transfer in marine ecosystems.  Forms the base of the microbial food web.

Includes phytoplankton (diatoms, dinoflagellates, cyanobacteria) and other photosynthetic organisms.  Forms the base of the pelagic food web, responsible for primary production and oxygen generation.  Characterized by high P/B ratios.
Consumes phytoplankton and other primary producers.  Important for transferring energy from primary producers to higher trophic levels.  Often small and abundant.

Top predators in the pelagic zone.  Important for regulating populations of smaller organisms.  Often have high energy requirements and long lifespans.

Includes bacteria, archaea, and protists that form the base of the microbial food web.  Important for nutrient cycling and energy transfer in the ocean.

Includes phytoplankton (diatoms, dinoflagellates, cyanobacteria) and other photosynthetic organisms.  Forms the base of the pelagic food web, responsible for primary production and oxygen generation.  Characterized by high P/B ratios.
Consumes phytoplankton and other primary producers.  Important for transferring energy from primary producers to higher trophic levels.  Often small and abundant.
Predates on herbivores and other small organisms.  Includes a variety of small fish, squid, and crustaceans.  Important for regulating herbivore populations.
Larger predators that feed on smaller pelagic organisms, including herbivores and smaller carnivores.  Important for regulating populations and transferring energy up the food web.

Organisms that live on the seafloor.  Includes a diverse range of invertebrates with various feeding strategies (detritivores, predators, filter feeders).  Important for nutrient cycling and sediment stability.
Includes fish and squid species that are heavily fished for human consumption.  These species are often top predators and play a significant role in fisheries and food security.
Organisms that feed on dead organic matter.  Important for nutrient cycling and waste removal.  Often have high tolerance for low oxygen conditions.
Organisms that filter feed on particles suspended in the water column.  Important for removing particulate matter and transferring energy from phytoplankton to higher trophic levels.

functional_groups.description: Large, high‑trophic‑level pelagic predators targeted by high‑value fisheries; fast‑swimming, migratory, surface‑oriented species with low P/B and Q/B ratios.
Fast‑moving, high‑trophic‑level pelagic fishes of commercial importance; include tunas, billfish relatives, and large pelagic predators with high Q/B and moderate P/B.
Short‑lived, high‑reproduction, primary consumers that form the main prey base for higher trophic levels; heavily fished for human consumption and fishmeal.
Demersal or reef‑associated species of high market or ornamental value; include groupers, triggerfish, angelfish and butterflyfish, generally mid‑trophic predators or omnivores.
Benthic and pelagic crustaceans harvested for high‑value seafood; characterized by fast turnover, high P/B, and strong susceptibility to over‑exploitation.
Fast‑growing, short‑lived pelagic and benthic cephalopods targeted by fisheries; high Q/B, low P/B, important for trophic transfer to higher predators.
Large, high‑trophic‑level sharks and related pelagic predators with low commercial value but key top‑down control; low P/B, low Q/B, vulnerable to by‑catch.
Medium‑size, fast‑swimming pelagic fishes that feed on zooplankton and small fishes; moderate P/B and Q/B, important energy conduits to higher predators.
Species inhabiting the twilight and deep zones; include lanternfishes, hatchetfishes, and various deep‑sea families; high P/B, low Q/B, crucial for carbon transport.
Herbivorous and omnivorous fishes that graze algae or detritus on coral reefs; moderate P/B, important for reef resilience and energy flow to higher trophic levels.
Bottom‑dwelling crustaceans, mantis shrimps and related taxa that feed on benthic invertebrates or detritus; high P/B, short life cycles, sensitive to habitat disturbance.
Primary consumers and secondary consumers in the water column; include copepods, euphausiids, amphipods, hyperiids and gelatinous taxa; high P/B, high Q/B, key link between phytoplankton and fish.
Photosynthetic micro‑algae and cyanobacteria that dominate primary production; very high P/B, low Q/B, foundation of the marine food web.
Bacteria, ciliates and pico‑/nano‑zooplankton that recycle dissolved organic matter; extremely high P/B and Q/B, essential for nutrient regeneration.
Non‑commercial, often fragile pelagic molluscs and pteropods that feed on small zooplankton; high turnover, low trophic impact but important for carbon flux.
Mid‑size to large squids and related taxa with low commercial value; fast growth, low P/B, high Q/B, serve as important prey for apex predators.
Species that live in association with larger hosts (e.g., remoras); low direct productivity but influence host dynamics and parasite loads.
Large, low‑productivity, surface‑dwelling fish with unique life history; low Q/B, low commercial value, but important as a mesopelagic‑to‑epipelagic connector.
Photosynthetic microorganisms that dominate primary production; very high P/B, low Q/B, the base of the marine food web.
Heterotrophic microbes and pico‑/nano‑zooplankton that recycle organic matter; extremely high P/B and Q/B, linking dissolved organic carbon back into the food web.
High-value, fast-growing, highly migratory apex predators occupying the top pelagic trophic level. Large body size, high P/B and Q/B ratios, heavily targeted by industrial fisheries.
Large, highly migratory shark species of commercial importance. Sit at the apex of the pelagic food web, with low P/B but high Q/B, vulnerable to over‑fishing.
Top‑level pelagic predators not primarily targeted by fisheries. Similar life‑history traits to commercial sharks but lower exploitation pressure.
Fast‑growing, highly mobile cephalopods that act as mesopelagic–pelagic predators. High trophic level, high Q/B, important prey for many fish and marine mammals.
Cephalopods with a demersal or benthic habit, moderate trophic level, relatively fast turnover (high P/B, moderate Q/B). Serve as important prey for reef and demersal predators.
Short‑lived, high‑reproduction, schooling fishes that dominate the mid‑pelagic trophic level. High P/B and Q/B, essential link between primary production and higher predators.
Medium‑sized, reef‑associated fishes that graze algae, scrape substrates or feed on detritus. High P/B, low Q/B, critical for reef resilience and carbon recycling.
Demersal and reef‑associated predators with moderate growth rates and intermediate P/B ratios. Include many species of cultural and artisanal importance.

Mid‑water to benthic fishes occupying the mesopelagic to bathypelagic zones. Generally small‑bodied, fast‑metabolising, with high P/B and Q/B, forming a key link between primary production and apex predators.
Small, fast‑reproducing crustaceans and amphipods that dominate the upper trophic levels of the microbial loop. Very high P/B and Q/B, essential prey for many forage fishes.
Demersal crustaceans and other macro‑invertebrates with moderate growth rates and low trophic position. High P/B, low Q/B, important for benthic energy transfer.
Soft‑bodied, low‑density pelagic organisms (paper nautilus, heteropods, pteropods, sunfish) that occupy a range of trophic levels but have very high turnover rates and are often by‑catch.
Photosynthetic micro‑algae that form the base of the marine food web. Very high P/B, very low Q/B, primary source of organic carbon for higher trophic levels.
Bacteria, protozoa and tiny metazoans that recycle dissolved organic matter. Extremely high P/B and Q/B, linking dissolved nutrients to the classical food web.

Top-level piscivorous predators with high trophic levels, primarily inhabiting epipelagic to mesopelagic zones. These species are apex predators with high swimming capacity, large body size, and high commercial value. They feed on fish, squid, and crustaceans and are vulnerable to longline and purse-seine fisheries.

Large, mobile predatory sharks occupying mid to high trophic levels in open ocean ecosystems. These species have slow growth, low P/B ratios, and high vulnerability to overfishing. They play key roles in regulating mid-trophic fish and squid populations.

Small to medium-sized fish inhabiting mesopelagic zones with diel vertical migration behavior. They have moderate P/B and Q/B ratios, serve as critical trophic links between deep and surface food webs, and feed on zooplankton and micronekton. Include myctophids and other deep-water migratory species.

Demersal and reef-associated fish families with diverse feeding strategies including omnivory, herbivory, and predation. These species occupy complex habitats, have moderate life spans and P/B ratios, and contribute to benthic-pelagic coupling. Many are targeted in small-scale and artisanal fisheries.

Fish species associated with deeper continental shelf and slope habitats, including benthopelagic and demersal forms. They generally have low P/B ratios, slow growth, and high vulnerability to trawling and deep-sea fishing. Play roles in scavenging and benthic predation.

Fast-growing, short-lived mollusks with high metabolic rates and Q/B ratios. Occupy mid to high trophic levels as active predators on fish and crustaceans. Include squids and octopuses with significant roles in energy transfer and as prey for larger predators. Some species are commercially fished.

Swimming crustaceans including euphausiids, sergestids, and pelagic decapods. Form dense aggregations and serve as key prey for fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. High biomass and moderate P/B ratios. Important in vertical carbon flux and trophic transfer.

Benthic-dwelling and larval-stage crustaceans including brachyuran zoea (megalopa), lobster and slipper lobster larvae, and reef-associated decapods. Serve as prey for demersal fish and contribute to benthic food webs. Include both planktonic larvae and benthic adults.

Small, mobile crustaceans often associated with gelatinous zooplankton or floating debris. Occupy mid-trophic levels, feeding on detritus and small organisms. Important in recycling and as prey for small fish. High abundance and turnover rates.

Aggressive benthic predators with strong raptorial appendages. Occupy reef and soft-bottom habitats, feeding on crustaceans and mollusks. Have moderate P/B ratios and contribute to benthic community structuring.

Includes gelatinous predators such as siphonophores and cnidarians (not explicitly listed but implied by ecological context). However, based on input, this group is not directly represented. Omitted due to lack of explicit taxa.
Shelled and soft-bodied holoplanktonic mollusks that feed on microzooplankton. Important in carbonate cycling and serve as prey for fish and cephalopods. Found in tropical to polar waters.
Epizoic fish with commensal relationships with larger pelagic hosts. Low abundance but ecologically distinct due to symbiotic lifestyle. Minimal direct fisheries impact.
Large, slow-growing pelagic fish with specialized diets (e.g., gelatinous zooplankton). Low P/B ratio, high vulnerability to bycatch. Play unique trophic roles in consuming understudied prey.
Surface-dwelling piscivores with elongated bodies, inhabiting coastal and open ocean waters. Feed on small fish and contribute to upper trophic levels in epipelagic food webs.

Heterotrophic and mixotrophic protists including ciliates, small dinoflagellates, and nanoflagellates. High P/B and Q/B ratios. Key grazers on phytoplankton and bacteria, forming a critical link to higher trophic levels.

Dominant primary producers in oligotrophic waters. Includes cyanobacteria with high abundance, rapid turnover, and foundational role in marine food webs. Low individual biomass but high total production.

Eukaryotic phytoplankton including diatoms, dinoflagellates, and other algal groups. Form blooms, contribute to carbon export, and support higher trophic levels. Vary in size and nutrient requirements.
Dominant mesozooplankton with high biomass and production. Key grazers on phytoplankton and prey for fish larvae and filter feeders. Include both adults and nauplii stages with high P/B ratios.
Cephalopod taxa of significant fisheries interest, separated from general cephalopods due to management relevance. Includes loliginid squids and ommastrephids targeted in global fisheries.

High-value tuna and billfish species subject to intense international fisheries. Separated from general pelagic predators for stock assessment and management purposes. Include yellowfin, bigeye, skipjack, and swordfish.
Shark families heavily targeted in global fisheries, especially for fins and meat. Separated for management due to conservation concerns and slow life histories.
Reef-associated fish families with high market value in tropical fisheries, including groupers, emperors, and snappers. Often subject to overfishing and habitat degradation.

Top-level piscivorous predators with high trophic levels, primarily occupying epipelagic and mesopelagic zones. These are large-bodied, fast-swimming species with high energy demands and significant roles in regulating mid-trophic fish populations. Many are targeted by commercial and recreational fisheries.

Medium to large pelagic elasmobranchs with high mobility, occupying mid to high trophic levels. These species are apex or mesopredators, feeding on fish and cephalopods. They have low P/B ratios, slow growth, and high vulnerability to overfishing.

Small to medium-sized fish inhabiting the mesopelagic zone with diel vertical migration behavior. These species link primary production to higher trophic levels, consuming zooplankton and micronekton. They have moderate P/B and Q/B ratios and are increasingly targeted in deep-sea fisheries.

Diverse group of benthopelagic and reef-associated fish with varied diets including planktivory, herbivory, and predation. These species occupy complex habitats and support artisanal and recreational fisheries. They exhibit moderate to high P/B ratios and contribute to energy transfer in nearshore systems.

Demersal and deep-sea fish with low metabolic rates, slow growth, and low P/B ratios. These species inhabit continental slopes and seamounts, feeding on benthic invertebrates and detritus. Highly vulnerable to deep-sea trawling and habitat disturbance.

Economically important squid and octopods with high growth rates, short lifespans, and high P/B and Q/B ratios. These are active predators occupying mid to high trophic levels, supporting major global fisheries. They play key roles in energy transfer and predator diets.

Smaller, short-lived cephalopods with limited commercial value. These occupy mid-trophic levels, serving as prey for fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. They have high turnover rates and contribute to vertical carbon flux.

Swimming crustaceans including krill, shrimp, and hyperiids that form dense aggregations in the water column. These are key herbivores and omnivores, transferring energy from primary producers to higher trophic levels. High P/B ratios and critical prey for fish, seabirds, and whales.

Benthic-dwelling and larval-stage crustaceans including lobster larvae, slipper lobster, and stomatopods. These occupy complex habitats and serve as prey for demersal fish. Megalopa represent a critical life stage with high mortality and recruitment variability.

Gelatinous zooplankton including siphonophores, ctenophores, and medusae analogs that prey on microzooplankton and ichthyoplankton. These are often under-sampled but can dominate biomass in certain systems and impact fish recruitment.

Minor benthic and pelagic invertebrates with limited data availability and low biomass contribution. These include rare or cryptic taxa with uncertain ecological roles but potential importance in benthic-pelagic coupling.
Specialized fish with commensal or symbiotic lifestyles, often associated with larger pelagic hosts. Low abundance but ecologically distinct due to unique trophic and habitat interactions.

Large, slow-moving pelagic fish with specialized diets (e.g., jellyfish, gelatinous zooplankton). Low P/B ratios, high vulnerability to bycatch, and unique trophic roles in consuming low-quality prey.
Rare, deep-sea fish with elongated bodies and benthopelagic habits. Poorly studied with likely low biomass and turnover, occupying detrital or piscivorous niches in deep ocean ecosystems.

Small heterotrophic and mixotrophic protists including ciliates, sarcodinids, and rotifers. These are primary consumers of bacteria and phytoplankton, with high P/B ratios and critical roles in the microbial loop and nutrient cycling.

Dominant herbivorous and omnivorous zooplankton, primarily copepods, that graze on phytoplankton and microzooplankton. High biomass and turnover, forming the base of the pelagic food web and key prey for larval fish and filter feeders.

Autotrophic organisms responsible for primary production in marine ecosystems. Includes picophytoplankton, nanophytoplankton, and microphytoplankton with high growth rates and central roles in carbon fixation and energy input.

Free-living bacteria that remineralize organic matter and support the microbial loop. High abundance and turnover, consuming dissolved organic carbon and serving as food for heterotrophic nanoflagellates and microzooplankton.

Small heterotrophic protists (2–20 μm) that consume bacteria and picophytoplankton. Bridge energy from the microbial loop to larger zooplankton and larval fish. High P/B and Q/B ratios, critical in nutrient regeneration.

Top-level piscivorous predators with high trophic levels, primarily inhabiting epipelagic to mesopelagic zones. These are large-bodied, fast-swimming species with high energy demands and significant roles in regulating mid-trophic fish populations. Many are apex predators and highly vulnerable to fisheries.

Medium to large pelagic elasmobranchs with high mobility and predatory feeding behavior. These occupy mid to high trophic levels, preying on fish and cephalopods. They have low P/B ratios, slow growth, and high vulnerability to overfishing.

Highly migratory, commercially valuable species targeted by industrial and artisanal fisheries. These species support major global fisheries and have significant economic and cultural importance. Managed internationally due to transboundary distributions.

Small to medium-sized deep-water fish performing diel vertical migrations. They link primary production to higher trophic levels, feeding on zooplankton and serving as prey for larger pelagics. Characterized by moderate P/B and Q/B ratios and high biomass.

Fish associated with deep-sea and benthopelagic habitats, often with slow growth, low metabolic rates, and low P/B ratios. They occupy diverse trophic roles from detritivory to predation and are vulnerable to deep-sea fishing pressures.

Demersal and reef-associated fish families with diverse feeding strategies including herbivory, planktivory, and predation. These occupy complex habitats, support artisanal fisheries, and play key roles in reef ecosystem dynamics.

Small to medium-sized pelagic fish including scombrids and relatives. They form schools, feed on zooplankton and small nekton, and serve as forage for larger predators. Moderate P/B and Q/B ratios with high ecological connectivity.

Fast-growing, short-lived mollusks with high metabolic and consumption rates. They occupy mid to high trophic levels as active predators on fish and crustaceans. High P/B ratios and important as both prey and predators in pelagic food webs.

Shrimp, lobster, and crab-like crustaceans including pelagic and benthic forms. They serve as mid-trophic omnivores and predators, with some species performing vertical migrations. Include commercially important taxa and key prey items.

Small, shrimp-like crustaceans forming dense aggregations in the water column. Primary consumers of phytoplankton and key prey for fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. High biomass and central to energy transfer in pelagic systems.

Diverse crustacean zooplankton including amphipods, hyperiids, and stomatopods. Occupy various trophic roles from herbivory to predation. Important in mid-trophic energy transfer and as prey for small fish.

Cnidarians, ctenophores, and gelatinous tunicates with low biomass turnover but high ecological impact. Often increase in disturbed ecosystems. Feed on microzooplankton and small zooplankton, and are increasingly recognized in food web models.

Heterotrophic and mixotrophic protists including ciliates, flagellates, and small dinoflagellates. Key grazers of phytoplankton and bacterioplankton, transferring energy to higher trophic levels. High P/B and Q/B ratios with rapid turnover.

Primary producers forming the base of the marine food web. Include picophytoplankton, nanophytoplankton, and diatoms. Differ in size, growth rates, and nutrient requirements. Drive primary production and carbon fixation.

Free-living bacteria involved in decomposition and nutrient cycling. Utilize dissolved organic matter and support the microbial loop. Serve as food for heterotrophic nanoflagellates and contribute to system respiration.

Small heterotrophic protists and bacteria that consume bacteria and phytoplankton. Bridge the gap between microbial loops and classical food chains. High turnover rates and essential for energy transfer efficiency.

Gelatinous filter feeders, including appendicularians, that build mucous feeding structures. Efficiently consume small particles and phytoplankton, contributing to carbon export. Often overlooked but ecologically significant.

Reef-associated and coastal fish species of high commercial or cultural value, often targeted by small-scale and recreational fisheries. Include groupers, snappers, emperors, and parrotfishes. Subject to overexploitation and habitat degradation.

Cephalopod species adapted to deep pelagic and benthic environments, often with specialized feeding and reproductive strategies. Contribute to deep-sea food webs and are increasingly vulnerable to deep-sea trawling.

Photosynthetic organisms forming the base of the food web. Include diatoms, nanoflagellates, and cryptophytes. These taxa are critical for carbon fixation, support higher trophic levels, and exhibit high P/B and Q/B ratios. They dominate pelagic environments and are highly sensitive to climate-driven changes in stratification and nutrient availability.

Small, pelagic zooplankton that consume phytoplankton and serve as a critical energy transfer link between primary producers and higher trophic levels. High P/B and Q/B ratios; include dominant Antarctic species with high reproductive rates and sensitivity to environmental change. Notably include Euphausia superba, which is ecologically and commercially vital.

functional_groups.group_name: Commercially Important Pelagic Predators (Krill and Fish)
functional_groups.description: Species with high commercial value (e.g., krill fisheries) and significant ecological roles as mid-trophic level consumers. Include both krill and key fish species. These taxa have moderate to high P/B ratios, are pelagic, and are vulnerable to overfishing and climate change. They are central to energy transfer in the Southern Ocean food web.

Pelagic predators that are ecologically important but not currently targeted by commercial fisheries. These taxa occupy mid-to-high trophic levels, have moderate P/B and Q/B ratios, and play key roles in energy transfer. Include species with similar life history strategies and habitat use as commercial species but lacking direct fishery pressure.

Highly mobile, large-bodied cetaceans that are apex predators or near-apex consumers. They have low P/B ratios, high body size, and long life histories. These species are vulnerable to climate change, ship strikes, and noise pollution. They play a critical role in nutrient cycling and top-down control of mesozooplankton and fish populations.

Marine mammals that occupy mid-to-high trophic levels, primarily feeding on fish and krill. They exhibit moderate P/B ratios, are highly mobile, and are sensitive to changes in prey availability and sea ice. These species are ecologically important for energy transfer and are vulnerable to climate change and human disturbance.

Birds that forage in the pelagic zone and on sea ice, feeding on krill, fish, and invertebrates. They have high Q/B ratios, are sensitive to changes in sea ice and prey availability, and play key roles in nutrient transport and ecosystem connectivity. Include both breeding and migratory species.

Invertebrates that live on or in the seafloor, playing key roles in nutrient recycling, detritus processing, and benthic-pelagic coupling. Include polychaetes, gastropods, and echinoderms. These taxa have low to moderate P/B ratios, are long-lived, and are vulnerable to bottom trawling and habitat degradation.

Photosynthetic organisms forming the base of the food web. Include diatoms, nanoflagellates, and cryptophytes. These taxa are critical for carbon fixation, support higher trophic levels, and exhibit high P/B and Q/B ratios. They dominate pelagic environments and are highly sensitive to climate-driven changes in sea ice and nutrient availability.

Key herbivorous zooplankton that consume phytoplankton and transfer energy to higher trophic levels. Include Antarctic krill and related species with high biomass turnover (high P/B), central to energy transfer in Southern Ocean food webs. Highly vulnerable to climate change and commercial harvesting.

Large, gelatinous or soft-bodied organisms that consume plankton and small nekton. Include salps and certain squid species. These taxa have high consumption rates (Q/B), moderate P/B, and play a role in carbon export via sinking fecal pellets. They are ecologically important but often overlooked in traditional models.

Invertebrates inhabiting the seafloor that feed on detritus, meiofauna, and other benthic organisms. Include polychaetes, gastropods, and echinoderms. These taxa have low to moderate P/B ratios, contribute to nutrient recycling, and are sensitive to physical disturbance and climate change.

Cold-adapted, slow-growing fish species that occupy mid-trophic levels in pelagic and benthic habitats. Include species like Notothenia rossii and Gobionotothen gibberifrons. They have low P/B and Q/B ratios, serve as key prey for higher predators, and are vulnerable to overfishing and warming waters.

High trophic level, large-bodied whales that consume krill, fish, and squid. Include blue, fin, and minke whales. These species have low P/B ratios, long life spans, and are highly vulnerable to historical and ongoing anthropogenic pressures. They play a critical role in nutrient cycling and ecosystem regulation.

Apex predators that consume fish, squid, and marine mammals. Include sperm whales and orcas. These species have low P/B ratios, high trophic levels, and are sensitive to pollution, noise, and prey depletion. They are ecologically significant but often underrepresented in models.

Pinnipeds that occupy mid-to-high trophic levels, feeding on fish, squid, and krill. Include Antarctic fur seals, crabeater seals, and leopard seals. They have moderate P/B ratios, are highly mobile, and are sensitive to climate change and fisheries interactions. Some species are commercially important.

Flightless seabirds that forage in the pelagic zone, feeding on krill, fish, and squid. Include Adélie, chinstrap, gentoo, and emperor penguins. They have moderate P/B ratios, are key indicators of ecosystem health, and are sensitive to climate change and fisheries. Some species are culturally significant.

Birds that forage in open water and coastal zones, consuming fish, krill, and invertebrates. Include albatrosses, petrels, and storm-petrels. They have moderate to high Q/B ratios, are long-lived, and serve as indicators of marine productivity. Some are vulnerable to bycatch and habitat loss.

Species with documented commercial or cultural significance, including fisheries targets and culturally important species. These taxa are managed separately due to their economic value and vulnerability to overexploitation. Includes krill, certain fish, and penguins in some regions.

Photosynthetic organisms forming the base of the food web. Include diatoms, nanoflagellates, and cryptophytes. These taxa are critical for carbon fixation, support higher trophic levels, and exhibit high P/B and Q/B ratios. They dominate pelagic environments and are highly sensitive to climate-driven changes in sea ice and nutrient availability.

Key herbivorous zooplankton that consume phytoplankton and transfer energy to higher trophic levels. Include Antarctic krill and related species with high P/B ratios, strong pelagic distribution, and central roles in energy transfer. Highly vulnerable to climate change and commercial harvesting.

Large, filter-feeding organisms that consume zooplankton and small organisms. Include salps and certain squid species. These taxa have moderate to high P/B ratios, occupy open pelagic zones, and play a role in carbon export via sinking fecal pellets. Less vulnerable to fishing but sensitive to ecosystem shifts.

Invertebrates inhabiting the seafloor, including echinoderms, polychaetes, and gastropods. These taxa are detritivores or omnivores with low to moderate P/B ratios, contribute to nutrient recycling, and form the foundation of benthic food webs. Highly sensitive to physical disturbance and climate change.

Cold-adapted fish species with low metabolic rates and slow growth. Include icefish and related taxa. They occupy mid-trophic levels, exhibit low P/B and Q/B ratios, and are key prey for higher predators. Vulnerable to warming and overfishing due to limited dispersal and life history traits.

High-trophic-level, large-bodied whales that consume krill, fish, and squid. Include baleen whales with high energy demands and low reproductive rates. These taxa are ecologically significant for nutrient cycling and are vulnerable to historical and ongoing exploitation, climate change, and ship strikes.

High-trophic-level, large-bodied toothed whales that consume fish, squid, and marine mammals. Include sperm whales and orcas. These taxa have low P/B ratios, high energy demands, and are sensitive to pollution, noise, and prey depletion. Orca populations are particularly vulnerable due to specialized diets and social structure.

Pinnipeds that occupy mid-to-high trophic levels, feed on fish, krill, and squid, and exhibit moderate P/B ratios. Include both Antarctic and sub-Antarctic species. They are ecologically important as predators and prey, and are vulnerable to climate change, habitat loss, and historical hunting.

Flightless seabirds that forage in pelagic zones, feeding on krill, fish, and squid. Include Adélie, chinstrap, gentoo, and emperor penguins. They are key indicators of ecosystem health, have moderate P/B ratios, and are sensitive to climate change, sea ice loss, and fisheries competition.
