Birds that forage in open ocean or coastal zones, feeding on fish, krill, and invertebrates. Include albatrosses, petrels, and skuas. They have moderate to high Q/B ratios, are long-lived, and are vulnerable to bycatch, pollution, and climate change. Play a role in nutrient transport via guano.

Species with significant commercial or cultural value, including krill and key fish species. These taxa are subject to regulated or unregulated harvesting and are central to ecosystem-based management. Their exploitation can disrupt food web dynamics and energy transfer.
Large marine mammals including whales, dolphins, and porpoises; apex predators with high trophic levels; primarily baleen whales (filter feeders) and toothed whales (predators)
Semiaquatic mammals including seals and sea lions; benthic or pelagic depending on species; include both carnivorous and filter-feeding behaviors
Flightless seabirds adapted to aquatic life; primarily benthic or ice-associated; important in polar food webs as predators and prey
Birds adapted to marine environments; include both pelagic and benthic species; important for nutrient transport and ecosystem connectivity
Small crustaceans forming large aggregations; key prey for many marine predators; high trophic level as primary consumers
Highly mobile invertebrates with complex behavior; important predators and prey in marine food webs
Bottom-dwelling organisms including polychaetes, gastropods, and echinoderms; play critical roles in benthic food webs and nutrient cycling
Includes phytoplankton like diatoms and nanoflagellates; form the base of marine food webs through photosynthesis
Include various species with different trophic roles and habitats; some are apex predators while others are prey for higher-level consumers
Elasmobranchs with diverse feeding strategies; some are apex predators while others target specific prey types
Include species that occupy both pelagic and benthic habitats; important for scavenging and predation
Predatory whales with specialized feeding behaviors; some are apex predators in marine ecosystems
Birds adapted to life in the open ocean; include species that are both pelagic and benthic feeders
Small crustaceans forming large aggregations; key prey for many marine predators; high trophic level as primary consumers
Include species with unique ecological roles or life history strategies; some are important for commercial fishing
Organisms that form the base of the food web through photosynthesis or other primary production processes.
Small, pelagic crustaceans that are key prey items for higher trophic levels in the ecosystem.
Diverse group of pelagic and benthic organisms occupying various trophic levels as both prey and predators.
Birds that primarily inhabit marine environments, serving as predators and scavengers.
Large marine mammals occupying apex predator roles with significant ecological impacts.
Bottom-dwelling organisms playing crucial roles in benthic food webs and ecosystem functioning.
Organisms that produce energy through photosynthesis or other autotrophic processes, forming the base of the food web.
Organisms that primarily consume plant material or filter plankton from the water, occupying lower trophic levels.
Organisms that feed on other animals, occupying higher trophic levels and playing key roles in regulating populations.
Bird species that primarily inhabit marine environments, often feeding on fish and marine invertebrates.
Larger marine animals that occupy the open ocean, often serving as apex predators and influencing ecosystem dynamics.
Species that occupy intermediate trophic levels, often serving as prey for larger predators.
Marine invertebrates with a water vascular system and typically pentamerous symmetry, playing roles in benthic ecosystems.
Molluscs with a distinct head and circular body, known for their intelligence and predatory roles.
Top predators feeding on marine mammals and birds. Includes killer whales and leopard seals.
Large filter-feeding whales consuming krill and small fish, commercially significant.
Birds preying on fish, squid, and krill. Includes penguins, albatrosses, petrels.
Predatory squid in the food web.
Mid-trophic level fish, both commercially and ecologically important.
Key zooplankton species feeding on phytoplankton.
Small zooplankton including tunicates and fish larvae.
Primary producers of the ecosystem.
Benthic organisms including echinoderms and polychaetes.
Epipelagic fish with unique ecological role.
Small seabirds feeding on crustaceans, commercially harvested.
Apex predators feeding on marine mammals, fish, and other prey. Ecologically and commercially significant.
Predators feeding on fish, squid, and krill. Key role in energy transfer as both predators and prey.
Filter-feeding baleen whales consuming krill and small fish. Ecologically significant as grazers.
Flightless birds preying on fish, squid, and krill. Important in pelagic ecosystems.
Birds feeding on fish, krill, and squid. Play role in transferring energy from pelagic to terrestrial ecosystems.
Fish species targeted by commercial fisheries, important in both ecology and economy.
Deep-sea fish feeding on smaller fish and krill. Contribute to pelagic food webs.
Small, shrimp-like crustaceans grazing on phytoplankton. Crucial in Antarctic food webs.
Pelagic tunicates filtering phytoplankton. Important in carbon cycling.
Microscopic primary producers at base of food web. Include cryptophytes and nanoflagellates.
Large phytoplankton cells with silica shells. Key in primary production.
Species inhabiting sea floor, including echinoderms and polychaetes. Diverse roles in benthic ecosystems.
Apex predators feeding on other marine mammals, fish, and squid. Play a crucial role in regulating higher trophic levels.
Primary producers forming the base of the food web through photosynthesis. Include both eukaryotic and prokaryotic organisms.
Krill and other small crustaceans that feed on phytoplankton, serving as a critical link between primary producers and higher trophic levels.
Organisms associated with the seafloor, including echinoderms and polychaetes that play roles in benthic-pelagic coupling.
Fish species of commercial importance, often targeted in fisheries. Include both pelagic and demersal species.
Predatory cephalopods feeding on fish and crustaceans. Play a key role in pelagic food webs.
Small fish species that are prey for larger predators. Often form schools and are important in energy transfer.
Birds that feed on fish, squid, and crustaceans. Play a role in transporting nutrients from sea to land.
Colonial tunicates that filter-feed on phytoplankton. Important in carbon cycling and vertical flux.
Flightless birds feeding on krill, fish, and squid. Key predators in Antarctic ecosystems.
Large marine mammals feeding on krill, fish, and plankton. Include both baleen and toothed whales.
Marine snails and slugs, often associated with benthic habitats. Play roles in grazing and decomposition.
Seabirds that feed on a variety of prey including fish, squid, and crustaceans. Include albatrosses and petrels.
Seabirds that primarily feed on zooplankton and small crustaceans.

Includes phytoplankton (diatoms, cryptophytes) and other microscopic algae.  Primary producers forming the base of the food web. High production to biomass ratio.  Vulnerable to ocean acidification and temperature changes.

Zooplankton that feed on phytoplankton.  Important link between primary producers and higher trophic levels.  Includes copepods and other small crustaceans.  Significant biomass and energy transfer.  Vulnerable to pollution and climate change.

Large whales that feed on krill and other small zooplankton using baleen plates.  Top predators in the pelagic zone, playing a crucial role in nutrient cycling.  Long lifespans, slow reproductive rates, and vulnerable to whaling and entanglement.
Predatory marine mammals that feed on fish, seals, and other marine animals.  Important regulators of prey populations.  Vulnerable to pollution, entanglement, and hunting.
Seabirds that feed on fish, krill, and squid.  Important indicators of ecosystem health.  Vulnerable to climate change, pollution, and overfishing of prey.
Seabirds that feed on fish, squid, and other marine organisms.  Diverse feeding strategies and habitat preferences.  Vulnerable to pollution, climate change, and habitat loss.

Invertebrates that live on the seafloor.  Includes echinoderms, polychaetes, gastropods, and other benthic organisms.  Important for nutrient cycling and habitat provision.  Vulnerable to habitat destruction and pollution.
Species of significant economic or cultural value.  Often subject to intense fishing pressure and require careful management.
Includes phytoplankton (diatoms, cryptophytes) and other microscopic photosynthetic organisms forming the base of the food web. High production, low biomass. Crucial for energy transfer.
Zooplankton that consume phytoplankton. Important link between primary producers and higher trophic levels.  Varied size and life history.
Large whales that feed primarily on krill.  High biomass, significant impact on krill populations and ecosystem structure.  Vulnerable to historical whaling and current environmental pressures.
Predatory whales that consume fish, seals, and other marine mammals.  Important top predators regulating prey populations.  Vulnerable to pollution and prey depletion.
Seabirds that primarily feed on fish, krill, and squid.  Important predators in the Antarctic ecosystem.  Vulnerable to climate change and fisheries.
Marine mammals that feed on fish, squid, and crustaceans.  Important predators and prey in the Antarctic ecosystem. Vulnerable to climate change and fisheries.
A diverse group of birds that feed on fish, squid, crustaceans, and carrion.  Important indicators of ecosystem health. Vulnerable to pollution and climate change.
Includes a variety of crustaceans, from small amphipods to large krill.  Important components of the food web, serving as prey for many predators.  Vulnerable to pollution and climate change.
Organisms living on the seafloor, including polychaetes, gastropods, and echinoderms.  Important for nutrient cycling and food web support.  Vulnerable to habitat degradation and pollution.
Species of significant economic value, often targeted by fisheries.  Management requires careful consideration of stock status and ecosystem impacts.
Includes phytoplankton (diatoms, cryptophytes) and other microscopic photosynthetic organisms forming the base of the food web. High production, low biomass. Crucial for energy transfer.
Zooplankton that consume phytoplankton. Important link between primary producers and higher trophic levels.  Varied size and life history.
Large whales that feed primarily on krill. High biomass, significant impact on krill populations and ecosystem structure.  Vulnerable to historical whaling and current environmental pressures.
Predatory marine mammals that consume fish, seals, and other marine animals.  Important top predators, influencing prey behavior and population dynamics.  Some species are commercially exploited.
Seabirds that feed on fish, krill, and squid.  Important predators in the Antarctic ecosystem.  Vulnerable to climate change and fisheries.
Marine mammals that feed on fish, squid, and crustaceans.  Important predators in the Antarctic ecosystem.  Vulnerable to climate change and fisheries.
Includes a variety of crustaceans, from small amphipods to large krill.  Important components of the food web, serving as prey for many predators and consuming detritus.
Marine snails that feed on algae, detritus, and other organic matter.  Important components of benthic communities.
Starfish, sea urchins, and other echinoderms that feed on algae, detritus, and other organic matter.  Important components of benthic communities.
Marine worms that feed on detritus, algae, and other organic matter.  Important components of benthic communities.
Taxa with significant commercial fisheries or cultural importance.  Often subject to intense fishing pressure and require careful management.

Top-level carnivores with high trophic levels, feeding on marine mammals, seabirds, and large fish. These species have low P/B and Q/B ratios, slow life histories, and are highly vulnerable to ecosystem perturbations. Include toothed whales and large seals.

Giant filter-feeding mysticetes that consume krill and other zooplankton at high trophic efficiency. Occupy a unique energy transfer role by consuming vast quantities of small prey. Characterized by very low P/B ratios, long lifespans, and high cultural and commercial historical significance. Separated due to conservation and management importance.

Smaller filter-feeding whales that consume krill and small pelagic crustaceans. Occupy mid-to-high trophic levels with moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. Play a significant role in pelagic energy transfer and are potential targets of emerging fisheries.

Carnivorous seals breeding on sea ice, feeding on fish, squid, and krill. Moderate P/B ratios, benthopelagic foragers, and important predators in Antarctic food webs. Include both high-trophic-level predators and mid-level consumers.

Commercially and ecologically significant otariids with high foraging activity, feeding on fish and squid. Higher P/B ratios than phocids, pelagic foragers, and sensitive to climate and fishery impacts. Separated due to historical exploitation and current management relevance.

Flightless seabirds with diverse diets ranging from krill to fish. Occupy mid-trophic levels, forage in pelagic zones, and serve as key bioindicators. High site fidelity and sensitivity to environmental change.
Large petrels and skuas that scavenge or prey on fish, squid, and other seabirds. High mobility, broad diets, and high Q/B ratios. Play critical roles in nutrient cycling and top-down regulation.

functional_groups.group_name: Southern Ocean Seabirds (Small Petrels and Prions)
functional_groups.description: Small to medium-sized pelagic seabirds feeding on zooplankton, fish, and squid. High P/B ratios, high abundance, and important mid-trophic link between plankton and predators.
Ice-associated seabirds feeding on krill and fish. Specialized for cold, high-latitude environments. Low to moderate P/B, important indicators of sea ice dynamics.
Mid-trophic-level fish that feed on zooplankton and are prey for top predators. Include myctophids and notothenioids. Moderate P/B and Q/B ratios, key energy conduits in pelagic food webs.
Fast-growing, high-turnover cephalopods with high P/B and Q/B ratios. Important prey for marine mammals and birds. Occupy mid-to-high trophic levels and contribute significantly to energy flux.

Gelatinous zooplankton with high filtration rates and boom-bust population dynamics. Can dominate plankton communities under certain conditions, altering energy flow from phytoplankton to higher trophic levels.

Keystone herbivorous zooplankton forming the primary link between primary producers and higher trophic levels. High abundance, moderate P/B, and central to Antarctic food web structure. Include commercially targeted species.
Small heterotrophic protists including nanoflagellates and ciliates that graze on phytoplankton and bacteria. High P/B ratios, rapid turnover, and critical in microbial loop energy transfer.
Small photosynthetic eukaryotes contributing significantly to primary production, especially in mixed or ice-edge waters. High P/B, fast growth, and important food source for microzooplankton.
Large, silica-shelled algae that dominate spring blooms. High biomass production, form the base of the classical food chain, and support krill and pelagic fish. High P/B during bloom periods.

Sessile and mobile seafloor organisms including echinoderms, polychaetes, and gastropods. Low P/B ratios, long-lived, and important in nutrient cycling and benthic-pelagic coupling. Serve as food for demersal fish and some seals.

Top-level carnivores with high trophic positions, feeding on marine mammals, seabirds, and large fish. These species have low P/B and Q/B ratios, slow life histories, and are highly vulnerable to ecosystem perturbations. Include toothed whales and large seals.

Giant filter-feeding mysticetes that consume krill and other zooplankton at high trophic efficiency. Occupy a key role in carbon sequestration and nutrient cycling. Have very low P/B ratios, long lifespans, and are historically targeted by commercial whaling.

Medium to large phocid seals that breed on sea ice and feed on fish and squid. Moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. Play important roles in energy transfer between mid-trophic levels and apex predators. Include krill- and fish-eating species.

Eared seals with higher metabolic rates and P/B ratios than phocids. Forage actively in pelagic zones, feeding on fish and squid. Highly mobile and sensitive to environmental change. Includes the only otariid in the list.
Flightless seabirds that are major consumers of krill, fish, and squid. Occupy mid- to upper trophic levels. High biomass and colony-dependent life history. Key indicators of ecosystem health.
Large, predatory or scavenging seabirds with broad diets including carrion, penguin chicks, and fish. High mobility and broad foraging ranges. Play roles as scavengers and mid-level predators.

Small to medium-sized flying seabirds that feed on zooplankton, fish, and squid in open water. High P/B ratios, short lifespans, and high sensitivity to prey availability. Include storm-petrels and prions.

Euphausiid crustaceans forming the core of the Antarctic food web. High biomass, moderate P/B, and central role in energy transfer from primary producers to higher trophic levels. Highly targeted by commercial fisheries.

Gelatinous zooplankton capable of rapid population blooms. Filter-feed on phytoplankton and microzooplankton. Compete with krill under warming conditions. High turnover rates and episodic dominance in carbon export.
Fast-growing, soft-bodied cephalopods with high Q/B and P/B ratios. Important prey for predators and mesopredators. Contribute to vertical energy transfer and are sensitive to oceanographic change.

Mid-trophic level fish that feed on zooplankton and are prey for seabirds, seals, and whales. Include myctophids and notothenioids with adaptations to cold waters. Moderate P/B and key in pelagic energy flow.

Photosynthetic organisms forming the base of the food web. Include diatoms, cryptophytes, and nanoflagellates. High turnover, high P/B, and responsible for primary production in pelagic and ice-associated environments.

Bottom-dwelling invertebrates including echinoderms, polychaetes, and gastropods. Contribute to benthic-pelagic coupling, nutrient recycling, and serve as food for demersal fish and some birds. Lower mobility and slower turnover than pelagic groups.

Ice-associated pelagic seabird with specialized diet and breeding on inland Antarctic cliffs. Low population density, high site fidelity, and sensitive to climate change. Ecologically distinct from other petrels.

Euphausia superba, specifically designated due to its high commercial value in fisheries for omega-3 supplements and aquaculture feed. Separated from other krill due to management and policy relevance.

Top-level carnivores with high trophic positions, feeding on marine mammals, seabirds, and large fish. These species have low P/B and Q/B ratios, slow life histories, and are highly vulnerable to ecosystem disturbances. Include killer whales and leopard seals.

Giant filter-feeding mysticetes that consume krill and small pelagic crustaceans. Occupy high trophic levels as primary consumers of zooplankton. High biomass, low P/B ratios, and long life spans. Play major roles in nutrient cycling and carbon sequestration. Highly sensitive to environmental change and historical exploitation.

Deep-diving, large odontocete predator specializing on squid and deep-water fish. High individual biomass, low P/B, and significant role in vertical nutrient transport. Occupies a unique trophic niche as a mesopelagic apex predator.

Carnivorous seals breeding on sea ice, feeding on fish, squid, and krill. Moderate P/B ratios, benthic-pelagic coupling role. Includes Weddell, leopard, crabeater, and southern elephant seals. Important prey for killer whales and orcas.

Commercially impacted, pelagic foraging pinnipeds with higher P/B ratios. Feed on fish and squid. Fast life history, sensitive to climate variability and fisheries interactions. Arctocephalus gazella is a key species in Southern Ocean food webs.

Flightless seabirds with high foraging demands, feeding on krill, fish, and squid. Occupy mid-to-upper trophic levels. Key indicators of ecosystem health. Differ in habitat use (ice-associated vs. ice-free), but share similar P/B and Q/B characteristics.

Large pelagic seabirds with low reproductive rates and high foraging ranges. Feed on fish, squid, and zooplankton. High trophic level, vulnerable to bycatch. Include albatrosses and giant petrels with similar life history and conservation concerns.

Mid-sized pelagic and coastal birds with higher P/B ratios. Include prions, storm-petrels, diving petrels, and skuas. Feed on zooplankton, fish, and carrion. More resilient life histories but sensitive to food availability and breeding site disturbance.

Ice-associated, high-latitude specialist seabird feeding on krill and fish. Low abundance, high vulnerability, and unique habitat requirements. Pagodroma nivea is ecologically distinct due to its extreme habitat specialization.

Mid-trophic level fish including myctophids and notothenioids. Key energy conduits between zooplankton and higher predators. Moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. Include commercially fished species like mackerel icefish.
Bottom-dwelling notothenioids with slower growth and lower P/B ratios. Feed on benthic invertebrates. Important in benthic-pelagic coupling. Include species like Gobionotothen gibberifrons.
Pelagic cephalopods of potential or current commercial interest. High growth and consumption rates (high Q/B), short life spans. Play significant role in energy transfer to higher predators.

Gelatinous zooplankton with high growth and filtering rates. Can dominate plankton blooms under warming conditions. High P/B, low trophic retention. Compete with krill and alter carbon export dynamics.

Keystone herbivorous zooplankton forming the core of the Antarctic food web. High biomass, moderate P/B, and central role in energy transfer from primary producers to higher trophic levels. Include Euphausia superba, E. crystallorophias, and Thysanoessa macrura.
Small heterotrophic plankton including nanoflagellates and ciliates. High P/B and Q/B ratios. Key grazers of phytoplankton and bacterial production. Mediate energy flow to higher trophic levels.

Photosynthetic organisms forming the base of the food web. Include diatoms, cryptophytes, and other phytoplankton. High production rates, short generation times. Drive seasonal blooms and carbon fixation in polar waters.

Sessile and mobile seafloor organisms including echinoderms, polychaetes, and gastropods. Low P/B ratios, long life spans. Important in nutrient recycling and benthic food webs. Vulnerable to bottom disturbance and climate change.
Apex pelagic predator, large-bodied, long-lived, culturally iconic. Feeds on fish, squid, and marine mammals. High P/B, low Q/B. Sensitive to prey availability and pollution.
Top ice‑associated predator, opportunistic feeder on penguins, fish, and other seals. Large body size, high trophic level, culturally significant.
Ice‑associated predator of fish and squid, relatively long‑lived, important cultural symbol of Antarctic ecosystems.
Specialist krill filter‑feeder, ice‑associated, high biomass, key link between krill and higher predators.
Pelagic predator of fish and squid, fast‑growing, commercially harvested in the past, culturally recognized.
Deep‑diving apex predator, feeds on squid and fish, very large body size, long life span, iconic species.
Deep pelagic apex predator of squid, long‑lived, high trophic level, culturally important marine mammal.
Largest filter‑feeder, consumes krill in open ocean, very low Q/B, high P/B, iconic megafauna.
Large pelagic filter‑feeder on krill and small fish, long‑lived, culturally significant.
Mid‑size filter‑feeder, feeds on krill, coastal‑pelagic, iconic species.
Smaller baleen whale, feeds on krill and small fish, relatively high turnover, culturally known.
Filter‑feeder that also engages in bubble‑net feeding, migratory, iconic for ecotourism.
Ice‑associated predator of fish, squid and krill; large, long‑breeding cycle, cultural emblem of Antarctica.
Coastal predator of krill and fish, fast‑growing, important indicator species.
Coastal predator of krill, high reproductive output, culturally recognized.
Coastal predator of fish and krill, relatively large clutch size, iconic bird.
Coastal predator of krill and fish, distinctive crest, culturally important.
Opportunistic predator and scavenger, feeds on carrion, fish, and squid; high trophic level, iconic seabird.
Pelagic surface feeder on zooplankton and small fish, moderate turnover, culturally known.
Predatory and scavenging seabird, feeds on eggs, chicks, fish and carrion; high Q/B.
Small pelagic surface feeder on zooplankton, high reproductive rate, iconic Antarctic bird.
Pelagic feeder on copepods and euphausiids, high turnover, culturally recognized.
Pelagic surface feeder on krill and fish larvae, moderate life span, iconic seabird.
Large pelagic soarer, feeds on fish, squid and carrion; long‑lived, culturally important.
Pelagic feeder on fish and squid, moderate life span, culturally known.
Pelagic bird feeding on krill and fish eggs, high reproductive output, iconic Antarctic bird.
Pelagic surface feeder on zooplankton and fish, moderate turnover, culturally recognized.
Pelagic surface feeder on zooplankton and small fish, high reproductive rate, iconic seabird.
Mid‑trophic nekton, fast‑growing, high Q/B, harvested for food; important energy conduit between lower and higher trophic levels.
Demersal fish of commercial value, moderate size, high turnover, important prey for seabirds and marine mammals.
Demersal fish targeted by fisheries, relatively fast growth, key prey for higher predators.
Includes Electrona antarctica (lanternfish) and Gobionotothen gibberifrons; small-bodied, high Q/B, primary consumers of zooplankton, important prey for many predators.
Pelagic gelatinous filter‑feeder, rapid reproduction, high Q/B, links phytoplankton production to higher trophic levels.
Dominant primary consumer, high biomass, harvested for feed and nutraceuticals; central to Antarctic food web.
Includes Thysanoessa macrura and Euphausia crystallorophias; similar ecology to E. superba but not targeted by fisheries.
Diatoms, nanoflagellates and cryptophytes; photosynthetic base of the food web, high P/B, short generation times.
Echinoderms, polychaetes and gastropods; diverse benthic community, moderate turnover, important prey for demersal fish and seals.
Photosynthetic microalgae forming the base of the Antarctic marine food web; high P/B, low Q/B; pelagic, small size, fast turnover.
Gelatinous zooplankton that filter phytoplankton and small particles; moderate P/B, high Q/B; occupy mid‑water column, important for carbon export.
Large euphausiid harvested for feed and nutraceuticals; high biomass, key prey for many predators; high Q/B, vulnerable to fishing pressure.
Smaller or less targeted krill species; similar trophic role to commercial krill but not directly fished; important secondary prey.
Demersal, commercially important fish; mid‑trophic predator on benthic invertebrates and zooplankton; moderate P/B, subject to fishing.
Pelagic to demersal fish targeted by fisheries; feeds on krill and small crustaceans; moderate life span, high economic value.
Bottom‑dwelling notothenioid harvested locally; feeds on benthic invertebrates; relatively short life cycle, vulnerable to trawl impacts.
Mid‑water cephalopod harvested for human consumption; opportunistic predator on fish and krill; fast growth, high Q/B, subject to targeted fisheries.
Large mysticetes that filter krill and small fish; very low P/B, long life spans, apex consumers of pelagic prey; not commercially fished.
Deep‑diving apex predator feeding on large squid; low P/B, high trophic level, long life history; not targeted by fisheries.
Top marine mammal predators including orcas and seals; consume fish, squid, and other marine mammals; low P/B, long-lived, sensitive to ecosystem changes.
Flightless seabirds that dive for fish, krill, and squid; mid‑trophic level, high Q/B, breeding colonies make them indicators of ecosystem health.
Highly mobile pelagic birds that capture prey at the surface (fish, squid, krill) and scavenge; moderate Q/B, long‑lived, vulnerable to by‑catch.
Small pelagic fish that feed on zooplankton and are prey for many higher predators; relatively fast turnover, moderate P/B.
Diverse benthic fauna including echinoderms, polychaetes, and gastropods; primary consumers and detritivores; high P/B, important for nutrient recycling.
Large pelagic mysticetes that filter‑feed on krill and small fish. High biomass, low production/biomass (P/B) ratios, primary consumers of zooplankton, key for carbon export.

functional_groups.group_name: Toothed Whales and Apex Marine Mammal Predators
functional_groups.description: Deep‑diving, high‑trophic‑level cetaceans that prey on fish, squid and other marine mammals. Low P/B, high consumption/biomass (Q/B) ratios, vulnerable to by‑catch and climate change.
Top‑predatory pinniped that hunts penguins, fish and other seals. High trophic level, high Q/B, limited commercial value but ecologically important.
Seals that primarily consume Antarctic krill or forage on the benthos. Mid‑to‑high trophic level, moderate Q/B, important links between pelagic production and benthic habitats.
Species targeted by fisheries (e.g., for human consumption). Mid‑trophic, relatively high Q/B, subject to direct fishing pressure and ecosystem‑based management.
Highly abundant, fast‑growing mesopelagic fish that feed on zooplankton and are prey for many higher predators. High Q/B, important energy conduit.
Open‑water squid that predate on fish, krill and other cephalopods. High Q/B, rapid turnover, key prey for many marine mammals and seabirds.
Colonial, flightless birds that forage in the water column on krill, fish and squid. Mid‑trophic, moderate Q/B, sensitive to sea‑ice changes and fisheries.
A diverse assemblage of surface‑feeding and soaring birds that consume fish, krill, squid and carrion. Generally high Q/B, vulnerable to climate‑driven prey shifts and by‑catch.
Dominant zooplankton that graze on phytoplankton and are the main prey for many higher trophic groups. High P/B, moderate Q/B, central to energy flow.
Pelagic tunicates that filter small phytoplankton and bacteria. Very high P/B, low Q/B, can dominate biomass during certain bloom conditions.
Macro‑invertebrates living on or in the seafloor, feeding on detritus, sediments and small organisms. Moderate P/B, important for benthic‑pelagic coupling.
Microscopic photosynthetic organisms that convert inorganic carbon into organic matter. Very high P/B, low Q/B, base of the Antarctic marine food web.

Apex predators with large body size, low reproductive rates, and high trophic position. They occupy the pelagic zone, feed on fish, squid, and krill, and play a key role in nutrient cycling and energy transfer to higher trophic levels.

Large, mid‑level predators that feed primarily on fish and krill. They are pelagic but often use ice habitats, and their foraging behavior influences nutrient redistribution and prey population dynamics.

Highly mobile, mid‑level predators that forage on fish, krill, and other zooplankton. They occupy pelagic and nearshore habitats and are important for linking lower trophic levels to larger predators.
Small, cold‑water fish that occupy benthic or demersal zones near sea‑ice. They are key prey for larger predators and contribute to the energy flow from primary production to higher trophic levels.
Mid‑level predators that feed on fish and krill and serve as important prey for large cetaceans and seabirds. They have rapid growth and high turnover, making them sensitive to environmental changes.
High‑production, commercially harvested krill species that form the base of the Antarctic food web. Their abundance and harvest rates are critical indicators for ecosystem management.
Krill species not currently harvested commercially but functionally similar to commercial krill, contributing to energy transfer and serving as prey for higher trophic levels.
Primary consumers that feed on phytoplankton and provide a major energy source for higher trophic levels. They are highly productive and sensitive to changes in primary production.
Detritivores and filter feeders that occupy the benthic zone. They recycle nutrients and provide food for demersal fish and benthic‑feeding marine mammals.
Microalgal communities that form the base of the Antarctic food web. They convert inorganic carbon into organic matter and support all higher trophic levels.

Large pelagic predators that occupy the top trophic level, feeding on fish, squid, and other marine mammals. They have high production to biomass ratios, large body size, and are key drivers of energy transfer in the pelagic ecosystem. Their vulnerability is mainly due to bycatch and habitat disturbance.

Massive filter‑feeding whales that consume large volumes of krill and other small zooplankton. They have low production to biomass ratios but high overall biomass, and play a critical role in nutrient recycling and carbon export. They are less affected by fishing but are sensitive to changes in krill abundance caused by climate change.

Marine mammals that feed on fish, krill, and benthic invertebrates. They have moderate production to biomass ratios, occupy near‑shore to benthic habitats, and are important for local nutrient cycling. Their main threats are bycatch, habitat degradation, and changes in prey distribution.

Diving seabirds that feed primarily on fish and krill. They are culturally significant, have high production to biomass ratios, and are sensitive to climate change, fisheries pressure, and habitat loss.

Pelagic seabirds that forage over large oceanic distances, feeding on fish, squid, and krill. They have moderate production to biomass ratios and are important for nutrient transport. Their main threats are bycatch, plastic ingestion, and changes in prey availability.

Key prey species that feed directly on phytoplankton and form the base of the Antarctic food web. They have high production to biomass ratios, are harvested commercially for fish feed, and are highly vulnerable to climate change and over‑exploitation.

Filter‑feeding zooplankton that contribute to rapid nutrient cycling and can form large blooms. They have low trophic levels, high production, and are sensitive to changes in water temperature, salinity, and prey availability.

Mid‑level predators that feed on fish and krill, and serve as important prey for larger seabirds and marine mammals. They have moderate production to biomass ratios and are vulnerable to fishing pressure and climate change.

Base of the marine food web, these photosynthetic organisms convert inorganic carbon into organic matter. They have high production rates and are sensitive to changes in light, temperature, and nutrient availability.

Benthic organisms that process detritus and small prey, contributing to nutrient recycling on the sea floor. They have moderate production to biomass ratios and are vulnerable to bottom trawling and habitat degradation.

Small, fast‑growing fish that feed on zooplankton and serve as a critical link between lower trophic levels and larger predators. They have moderate production to biomass ratios and are affected by changes in prey availability and fishing pressure.

Species that do not fit into the major marine mammal categories above. Their ecological roles are less well defined but they may contribute to local food webs and are potentially vulnerable to environmental changes.
Large baleen and toothed whales that occupy the upper pelagic zone, serve as apex predators and key drivers of nutrient cycling, long‑lived, vulnerable to climate change and historical whaling.
Large seals and sea lions that forage in benthic and pelagic habitats, important predators of fish and krill, long‑lived, vulnerable to hunting and climate change.
A highly mobile apex predator with a diverse diet, important for regulating prey populations, vulnerable to prey availability and pollution.
Culturally iconic, diverse species that feed primarily on fish and krill, important for nutrient transport, vulnerable to climate change and fisheries.
Includes petrels, albatrosses, gulls, skuas, and shearwaters; mid‑level predators and scavengers, important for nutrient cycling, vulnerable to bycatch and climate change.
Small fish, squid, lanternfish, and notothen species that consume zooplankton and serve as prey for larger predators, key energy transfer in the pelagic ecosystem.
Primary consumers of phytoplankton that form the base of the Antarctic food web, high production, vulnerable to overfishing and climate change.
Euphausia superba, the main species harvested for fish feed and aquaculture, high production, subject to fisheries management and ecosystem impacts.
Benthic organisms such as sea urchins, echinoderms, polychaetes, and gastropods that contribute to benthic‑pelagic coupling and nutrient recycling, vulnerable to habitat disturbance.
Phytoplankton groups including cryptophytes, nanoflagellates, and diatoms that provide the base of the food web, high production, sensitive to temperature and nutrient changes.
Organisms that produce energy through photosynthesis, forming the base of the food web.
Plant-eating organisms that graze on algae and other plant material.
Small to medium-sized fish that feed primarily on plankton, occupying a lower trophic level.
Fish that feed on other fish and invertebrates, occupying a middle trophic level.
Top predators that play a crucial role in maintaining ecosystem balance, including both pelagic and benthic species.
Large marine mammals that are apex predators, including whales and dolphins.
Highly migratory apex predators that occupy the upper trophic levels in pelagic ecosystems.
Highly intelligent predators that occupy a variety of trophic levels, from mesopredators to apex predators.
Invertebrates that include a variety of species from small crabs to large lobsters, playing roles as both prey and predators.
Marine invertebrates that include sea stars, sea urchins, and brittle stars, often functioning as benthic predators.
Invertebrates with soft bodies enclosed in a shell, including bivalves and gastropods, often serving as prey or detritivores.
Small drifting organisms that form a critical link between primary production and higher trophic levels.
Organisms that feed on dead organic material, playing a key role in nutrient recycling.
Species of significant economic or cultural importance, often managed separately for conservation and sustainable use.
Organisms that produce energy through photosynthesis, forming the base of the food web.
Plant-eating organisms that graze on algae and seagrasses, contributing to nutrient cycling.
Predatory fish and marine animals that feed on other organisms, playing a key role in regulating populations.
Organisms that consume dead organic matter, aiding in decomposition and nutrient recycling.
Marine invertebrates living on the ocean floor, including crustaceans and molluscs.
Fish species that inhabit the open water column, often migratory and planktonic feeders.
Fish species dependent on coral reefs for habitat and food, supporting reef ecosystems.
Apex predators with large body sizes and significant ecological influence.
Marine molluscs with complex life cycles, playing roles as both predators and prey.
Hard-shelled arthropods including crabs, lobsters, and shrimps, often benthic.
Soft-bodied invertebrates with diverse feeding strategies and habitats.
Marine invertebrates including starfish, sea urchins, and sea cucumbers.
Jellyfish and corals that play crucial roles in marine ecosystems.
Highly valued fish species with significant economic importance.
Top-level predators including whales, dolphins, and large sharks.
High-trophic level fish including tuna, swordfish, and billfish.
Varied group of cartilaginous fish, including both pelagic and benthic species.
Invertebrates including octopuses, squids, and cuttlefish.
Bottom-dwelling invertebrates such as crabs, lobsters, and mollusks.
Fish that primarily consume algae or plant material.
Fish that feed on plankton, occupying mid-trophic levels.
Fish and invertebrates closely associated with coral reefs.
Gelatinous plankton and other drifting invertebrates.
Photosynthetic organisms forming the base of the food web.
Organisms that process organic matter from dead organisms.

Primary producers forming the base of marine food webs; small, photosynthetic organisms with high P/B and Q/B ratios; critical for energy input and carbon fixation; highly sensitive to environmental changes and nutrient availability.

Macrophytic primary producers in coastal benthic habitats; moderate P/B ratios; provide habitat, nursery grounds, and food for herbivores; vulnerable to physical disturbance, eutrophication, and climate change.

Small, drifting heterotrophs feeding on phytoplankton and detritus; high Q/B and P/B ratios; key link between primary producers and higher trophic levels; sensitive to temperature, acidification, and overfishing of predators.

Organic particulate matter from dead organisms and waste; low P/B and Q/B ratios; serves as a critical energy source for detritivores and decomposers; central to nutrient cycling and benthic food webs.

Small, schooling fish feeding primarily on zooplankton and phytoplankton; moderate P/B and high Q/B ratios; key intermediaries in energy transfer; highly vulnerable to climate shifts and overfishing; include species like sardines and anchovies.

High trophic level, mobile predators with high Q/B and moderate P/B ratios; include fast-swimming, apex or near-apex predators; play key roles in top-down control; highly vulnerable to overfishing and bycatch.

Midwater and deep-living predatory fish and squids with low metabolic rates and low P/B ratios; occupy intermediate to high trophic levels; important for vertical energy transfer; sensitive to deep-sea mining and climate change.
Predatory fish inhabiting the seafloor; moderate to high trophic levels; low to moderate P/B ratios; include species with varied life histories; vulnerable to bottom trawling and habitat degradation.
Predatory invertebrates on the seafloor; include crustaceans and echinoderms; moderate to high trophic levels; low P/B ratios; important for benthic community structure and nutrient cycling.

Invertebrates feeding on organic matter in sediments; low to moderate trophic levels; low P/B and Q/B ratios; critical for nutrient recycling and sediment stability; sensitive to trawling and pollution.
Highly mobile, intelligent invertebrates with high Q/B ratios; occupy various trophic levels; important as both predators and prey; sensitive to climate change and fishing pressure.

High trophic level, long-lived cetaceans with low P/B ratios; include large whales and dolphins; play key roles in nutrient cycling and ecosystem structure; highly vulnerable to ship strikes, noise pollution, and bycatch.

Large, long-lived reptiles with varied diets (herbivores, omnivores, carnivores); moderate P/B ratios; important for seagrass and coral reef health; highly vulnerable to bycatch, habitat loss, and climate change.

Aerial predators feeding on fish and invertebrates; high mobility and energy demands; moderate to high Q/B ratios; sensitive to overfishing and pollution; important indicators of marine ecosystem health.
Species with significant economic and cultural value; include high-trophic-level, slow-growing species; often overfished; require targeted management and conservation strategies.
High-value crustaceans and mollusks with significant fisheries; often slow-growing and long-lived; vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation; require sustainable harvesting practices.
Invertebrates not targeted by fisheries but ecologically important; include filter feeders, grazers, and detritivores; support ecosystem functions and biodiversity.
Microscopic and gelatinous organisms forming the base of marine food webs; include zooplankton, jellyfish, and salps; high turnover rates; sensitive to climate change and ocean acidification.
Fish species not targeted by commercial fisheries but ecologically important; include small, abundant species and habitat specialists; support food webs and biodiversity.

Primary producers forming the base of marine food webs; small, photosynthetic organisms with high P/B and Q/B ratios; critical for energy input and carbon fixation; highly sensitive to environmental changes and nutrient availability.

Macrophytic primary producers in coastal benthic habitats; moderate P/B ratios; provide habitat, nursery grounds, and food for herbivores; vulnerable to physical disturbance, eutrophication, and climate change.

Heterotrophic planktonic organisms feeding on phytoplankton and detritus; intermediate trophic level; high Q/B and P/B ratios; key link in energy transfer from primary producers to higher trophic levels; sensitive to temperature and oceanographic changes.

Organic particulate matter derived from dead organisms and waste; serves as a critical energy source for detritivores and decomposers; low P/B and Q/B ratios; supports benthic food webs and nutrient cycling.

Small, schooling fish feeding primarily on zooplankton and detritus; low to medium trophic level; high P/B and Q/B ratios; key for energy transfer to higher predators; highly vulnerable to overfishing and climate-driven shifts.

Medium-sized predatory fish feeding on smaller fish and zooplankton; medium trophic level; moderate P/B and Q/B ratios; important for energy transfer in pelagic food webs; often targeted by fisheries.

Large, apex predators with high trophic level; low P/B and Q/B ratios; slow growth, long lifespan, low reproductive output; highly vulnerable to overfishing; play key roles in top-down control and ecosystem stability.
Fish species inhabiting the seafloor, feeding on invertebrates and small fish; medium to high trophic level; moderate P/B and Q/B ratios; sensitive to bottom trawling and habitat degradation.

Fish species associated with rocky reefs, seagrass beds, or coral habitats; diverse feeding strategies (herbivory, omnivory, predation); moderate to high P/B ratios; important for habitat maintenance and biodiversity; vulnerable to habitat loss and overfishing.
Highly mobile, predatory mollusks with high metabolic rates; high Q/B and P/B ratios; key predators and prey; sensitive to temperature and oxygen changes; important in energy transfer and fisheries.
Benthic crustaceans feeding on detritus, algae, or small invertebrates; moderate P/B ratios; important for nutrient cycling and as prey; sensitive to habitat degradation and pollution.

functional_groups.group_name: Benthic Invertebrates (Filter Feeders and Deposit Feeders)
functional_groups.description: Sessile or slow-moving invertebrates that filter water or consume sediment; low to moderate P/B ratios; critical for habitat engineering, nutrient cycling, and food web support; vulnerable to physical disturbance and pollution.

Free-floating gelatinous zooplankton; low P/B and Q/B ratios; high vulnerability to environmental change; can form blooms that disrupt food webs and fisheries; serve as prey for some fish and turtles.
Fish species of major economic and cultural significance; often targeted by fisheries; high vulnerability due to overfishing; include both pelagic and demersal species with slow life histories.
Crustaceans of high economic value; often targeted by fisheries; include spiny lobsters, crabs, and deep-sea species; slow growth and low reproductive output increase vulnerability to overfishing.
Cephalopods with significant fisheries value; high market demand; rapid growth and high turnover; sensitive to environmental variability and overfishing.

Species with critical ecological roles (e.g., habitat engineers, keystone predators, nutrient recyclers) but low or no commercial value; often overlooked in management; include many invertebrates and small fish.

Primary producers forming the base of marine food webs; small, photosynthetic organisms with high P/B and Q/B ratios; critical for energy input and carbon fixation; highly sensitive to environmental changes and nutrient availability.

Macrophytic primary producers in coastal benthic habitats; moderate P/B ratios; provide habitat, nursery grounds, and food for herbivores; vulnerable to physical disturbance, eutrophication, and climate change.

Small, drifting heterotrophs feeding on phytoplankton and detritus; high Q/B and P/B ratios; key link between primary producers and higher trophic levels; sensitive to temperature and oceanographic changes.

Organic particulate matter from dead organisms and waste; low metabolic activity but high turnover; supports detritivores and microbial loops; central to nutrient recycling and benthic energy pathways.

Small, schooling fish feeding primarily on zooplankton and detritus; moderate trophic level (2.0–2.5); high P/B and Q/B ratios; key energy transfer agents; highly vulnerable to overfishing and climate shifts.

Mid-sized predatory fish feeding on small fish and zooplankton; trophic level 3.0–3.5; moderate to high P/B and Q/B ratios; important for energy transfer in pelagic food webs; often targeted by fisheries.

Apex predators with high trophic level (4.0+); low P/B and Q/B ratios due to slow growth and long life; key for top-down control; highly vulnerable to overfishing and bycatch; include large sharks and billfish.

Fish inhabiting the seafloor, feeding on invertebrates and detritus; trophic level 2.5–3.5; moderate P/B and Q/B ratios; ecologically important for benthic-pelagic coupling; sensitive to bottom trawling.

Predatory invertebrates feeding on other benthic invertebrates and small fish; trophic level 3.0–4.0; moderate to high Q/B ratios; important for controlling prey populations and structuring benthic communities.
Invertebrates feeding on organic matter in sediments; trophic level 2.0–2.5; high P/B ratios; critical for nutrient cycling and sediment turnover; sensitive to pollution and habitat degradation.
Invertebrates associated with rocky or coral reefs; include grazers, filter feeders, and predators; moderate trophic levels; high biodiversity; vulnerable to habitat loss and climate change.
Pelagic fish species of high economic and cultural value; targeted by industrial and artisanal fisheries; include tunas, billfish, and large pelagic species; often overexploited and slow to recover.
Demersal fish species of high economic value; commonly caught by bottom trawling and gillnets; include flatfish, groupers, and deep-sea species; often overfished and slow-growing.

Invertebrates of high commercial value, including crustaceans, cephalopods, and echinoderms; targeted by fisheries; often have low resilience due to life history traits; key for food security and livelihoods.

Top predators with high trophic level and long life spans; low P/B and Q/B ratios; play key roles in ecosystem regulation; highly vulnerable to human impacts including bycatch, pollution, and climate change.

Apex predators with high trophic level, low reproductive rates, and high vulnerability to overfishing; critical for maintaining trophic balance; often targeted for fins and meat; slow to recover from population declines.
Pelagic and coastal birds feeding on fish and invertebrates; high mobility and energy demands; sensitive to food web disruptions and pollution; important indicators of ecosystem health.
Organisms that convert sunlight into biomass through photosynthesis, forming the base of the food web.
Small, often microscopic, animals that drift in the water column and feed on phytoplankton, playing a key role in transferring energy from primary producers to higher trophic levels.

Apex predators that occupy the highest trophic level in pelagic ecosystems, feeding on smaller fish and squid. These species are often of high commercial value and play a critical role in energy transfer pathways.
Species that are key intermediate predators in pelagic ecosystems, feeding on zooplankton and small fish while being preyed upon by larger predators.
Species that inhabit the seafloor or near-bottom waters, feeding on benthic organisms. These species often have slower growth rates and are vulnerable to bottom fishing gear.
Species that are typically found in coral or rocky reef ecosystems, playing important roles in maintaining the structure and function of these habitats.
Highly mobile, soft-bodied predators that play a key role in pelagic and benthic ecosystems. Many species are of commercial importance.
Apex predators that play a critical role in maintaining the balance of marine ecosystems. Many species are vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation.
Large, often apex predators that play a key role in maintaining the balance of marine ecosystems. These species are of high conservation and cultural importance.
Benthic and pelagic species that play important roles as both predators and prey in marine ecosystems. Many species are of commercial importance.
Benthic species that play important roles in maintaining the structure and function of marine ecosystems, particularly in coral reefs.
Organisms that feed on detritus, playing a key role in nutrient cycling and energy transfer in marine ecosystems.
Organisms that form the base of the food web through photosynthesis.
Small, usually microscopic, animals that drift in the water column and feed on phytoplankton.
Apex predators that are highly mobile and play a key role in pelagic ecosystems.
Active swimmers that feed on smaller fish and invertebrates.
Fish that live near the sea floor and feed on benthic organisms.
Fish adapted to deep-sea environments with limited light.
Marine animals with bilateral body symmetry, large heads, and tentacles.
Elasmobranchs that are apex predators or scavengers.
Animals with a hard exoskeleton and multiple limbs.
Slow-moving animals that live on or in the seabed.
Pelagic, carnivorous animals with stinging tentacles.
Dead and decaying organic matter that provides energy for decomposers.
Large marine mammals, apex predators feeding on fish, squid, and other marine life. Play a key role in maintaining ecosystem balance.
Reptiles, primarily herbivores or carnivores, contributing to coastal and marine ecosystem health.
Birds feeding on fish and squid, acting as top predators in marine ecosystems.
Apex predators maintaining trophic structure; some are commercially valuable.
Highly migratory, top predators in pelagic ecosystems; many are commercially important.
Schooling fish feeding on smaller organisms, crucial for energy transfer in pelagic ecosystems.
Inhabit deep waters, feeding on benthic organisms; often unique ecological roles.
Demersal species with varied diets, important in benthic ecosystems.
Large demersal predators; some are commercially valuable.
Varied species contributing to benthic food webs.
Smaller demersal species, often in coastal areas.
Species associated with reefs, contributing to biodiversity.
Important predators and prey in marine ecosystems; some commercial value.

groups.name: Marine Mammals (Apex Pelagic Predators)
groups.description: Large marine mammals that occupy the top of the pelagic food web, with low productivity, long life spans and high trophic positions.

groups.name: Sea Turtle
groups.description: Marine reptile that forages on benthic invertebrates and occasional fish, linking pelagic and benthic pathways.

groups.name: Seabirds (Pelagic)
groups.description: Highly mobile avian predators that feed on fish and zooplankton in the water column, linking surface production to higher trophic levels.

groups.name: Large Pelagic Commercial Predators (Tunas, Billfish, Wahoo, Amberjack)
groups.description: Fast‑moving, high‑trophic‑level fishes that dominate the upper pelagic food web and support major fisheries.

groups.name: Pelagic Sharks (Commercial & Bycatch)
groups.description: Apex predators of the open ocean, many of which are targeted or caught incidentally in pelagic fisheries.

groups.name: Small Pelagic Forage Fish
groups.description: Short‑lived, high‑reproduction fishes that form the core of the pelagic food chain and support many higher trophic levels.

groups.name: Demersal Commercial Groundfish & Deep Pelagic Species
groups.description: Mid‑trophic, primarily bottom‑associated fishes and deep‑water species that are important for commercial catches and link benthic production to higher predators.

groups.name: Reef-associated Commercial and Non‑commercial Fish
groups.description: Diverse assemblage of demersal and reef‑dwelling fishes, many of which support important Mediterranean fisheries and provide habitat complexity.

groups.name: Cephalopods (Squids, Octopus, Cuttlefish, Flying Squid)
groups.description: Fast‑growing, high‑trophic‑level molluscs that act as both predators and prey, linking lower trophic levels to top predators.

groups.name: Crustacean Fisheries (Lobsters & Shrimp)
groups.description: Benthopelagic crustaceans targeted by fisheries; important predators and scavengers on the sea floor.

groups.name: Crab Fisheries
groups.description: Various crab species and families harvested for food, representing an important benthic resource.

groups.name: Benthic Macroinvertebrate Community
groups.description: Diverse assemblage of sessile and mobile benthic invertebrates that recycle nutrients, graze primary producers and provide habitat complexity.

groups.name: Primary Producers (Phytoplankton, Seagrass/Seaweed)
groups.description: Photosynthetic organisms forming the base of marine food webs, converting inorganic carbon into organic matter.

groups.name: Zooplankton
groups.description: Small, drifting animals that feed on phytoplankton and serve as a key food source for many fish larvae and small pelagic fishes.

groups.name: Detritus
groups.description: Non‑living organic material that fuels the benthic food web and supports decomposer communities.

groups.name: Deep Sea Layer (DSL)
groups.description: Represents deep‑sea organic matter and associated processes not captured by other functional groups.

functional_groups.description: Primary producers forming the base of the marine food web. Microscopic autotrophic organisms that convert sunlight into biomass through photosynthesis. High P/B ratio, fundamental for energy input into the ecosystem.

Benthic primary producers including macroalgae and seagrasses. Provide habitat and food for herbivores, stabilize sediments, and contribute to coastal productivity. Lower turnover than phytoplankton but important structural role.

Small heterotrophic organisms that consume phytoplankton and microdetritus. Key link between primary producers and higher trophic levels. High P/B and Q/B ratios, short life cycles, and high turnover.
Non-living organic matter from decaying organisms and waste products. Serves as a major energy source for decomposers and detritivores. Critical for nutrient cycling and microbial loop.
Small schooling pelagic fish that feed on zooplankton. High P/B and Q/B ratios, short lifespans, and high reproductive output. Key prey for larger predators and important in energy transfer.
Midwater squid species with vertical migration patterns. Contribute to diel nutrient and carbon transport. Prey for large pelagics and marine mammals. Moderate to high P/B ratios.
Apex predatory fish with high trophic levels, feeding on forage fish and squid. High Q/B, moderate P/B, and slow growth. Include tunas and billfish with significant commercial value.
Mid-trophic pelagic fish that prey on smaller fish and cephalopods. Faster turnover than large pelagics, serve as both predator and prey. Include species with moderate commercial interest.
Benthopelagic and coastal shark species with diverse diets including fish, cephalopods, and crustaceans. Moderate to low P/B, slow growth, and high vulnerability to fishing pressure.
Deep-sea elasmobranchs with low metabolic rates, slow growth, and late maturity. Low P/B and Q/B ratios. Highly vulnerable to deep-sea fishing and habitat disturbance.
Deep-slope demersal fish feeding on benthic invertebrates and smaller fish. Moderate to low P/B, important in benthic-pelagic coupling. Some species are commercially targeted.
Shelf-dwelling bottom fish with varied diets including crustaceans and fish. Moderate P/B and Q/B. Many are commercially important and vulnerable to trawling.
Serranids, sparids, and other reef-associated fish of high commercial value. Often protogynous hermaphrodites, slow-growing, and vulnerable to overfishing.
Smaller reef fish with ecological roles in trophic regulation and habitat use. Faster turnover, less targeted by fisheries, but sensitive to habitat degradation.
Commercially valuable decapod crustaceans including lobsters and crabs. Low P/B, long lifespan, and high market value. Highly vulnerable to trapping and trawling.
Cephalopods and gastropods of commercial importance. Moderate P/B, high consumption rates, and key predators in benthic systems.
Non-targeted benthic invertebrates including echinoderms, polychaetes, and non-commercial crustaceans. Important for bioturbation, nutrient cycling, and as prey.
Apex consumers with low P/B, long lifespans, and high trophic levels. Play roles in nutrient transport and top-down regulation. Highly sensitive to environmental change and human impacts.
Long-lived reptiles with varied diets (e.g., jellyfish, seagrass). Low P/B, high conservation concern, and important for ecosystem balance and cultural value.
Pelagic birds feeding on fish and squid. Moderate P/B, high mobility, and indicators of ecosystem health. Sensitive to prey availability and fisheries bycatch.
Gelatinous zooplankton with high consumption rates and potential to dominate under eutrophic conditions. Can short-circuit food webs and impact fisheries.
Aggregation of mesopelagic organisms including fish, squid, and crustaceans that migrate vertically. Key in carbon flux and prey for deep-diving predators.
Cryptic benthic predators with high trophic levels. Feed on fish and crustaceans, occupy reef and rocky habitats. Moderate commercial interest in some regions.
Benthic ambush predators with venomous spines. Feed on small fish and crustaceans. Ecologically important on rocky reefs and vulnerable to habitat loss.
Benthic, camouflaged fish feeding on invertebrates and small fish. Low to moderate P/B, commercially valuable, and sensitive to bottom disturbance.

Primary producers forming the base of the marine food web. Microscopic autotrophic organisms that convert sunlight into biomass through photosynthesis. High P/B ratio, fundamental for energy input into the ecosystem.

Benthic primary producers including macroalgae and seagrasses. Provide habitat and food for herbivores, stabilize sediments, and contribute to coastal productivity. Moderate P/B, important for nearshore energy pathways.

Small heterotrophic organisms that consume phytoplankton and microdetritus. Key link between primary producers and higher trophic levels. High P/B and Q/B ratios, short life cycles, and high turnover.
Non-living organic matter from decaying organisms and waste. Serves as a major energy source for decomposers and detritivores. Critical for nutrient cycling and microbial loop dynamics.

Small, schooling, planktivorous or omnivorous fish occupying mid-trophic levels. High P/B and Q/B ratios, fast growth, and high vulnerability to fishing and environmental variability. Key prey for larger predators.
Large, fast-swimming predatory fish that feed on fish and squid. High trophic level, moderate P/B, high Q/B. Play a top-down regulatory role and are highly targeted by fisheries.
Bottom-associated fish inhabiting continental shelves, feeding on invertebrates and small fish. Moderate P/B and Q/B, important in benthic-pelagic coupling. Many are commercially valuable.
Fish associated with rocky reefs and complex habitats, often with territorial behavior and varied diets. Moderate life span and turnover. Ecologically important for reef resilience and structure.
Soft-bodied benthic invertebrates including cephalopods and polychaetes. High turnover and consumption rates. Important prey for fish and marine mammals. Contribute to nutrient cycling.
Hard-shelled benthic invertebrates including crustaceans, mollusks, and echinoderms. Lower P/B than soft-bodied groups, longer life spans. Provide structural habitat and are key in benthic food webs.
Pelagic sharks with high trophic positions, slow growth, and low P/B. Apex predators regulating mid-trophic levels. Highly vulnerable to overfishing due to life history traits.
Bottom-dwelling sharks and rays with specialized feeding strategies. Low P/B, long life spans, and high vulnerability. Important in benthic ecosystem dynamics and scavenging.
High trophic level, long-lived, slow-reproducing predators. Low P/B, high Q/B, and significant cultural and conservation value. Influence food web structure and are sensitive to environmental change.
Long-lived reptiles with varied diets (e.g., jellyfish, seagrass). Low P/B, high conservation priority. Play roles in nutrient transport and habitat maintenance.
Surface-foraging birds that feed on fish and squid. Moderate P/B, high mobility, and indicators of ecosystem health. Link marine and terrestrial systems.
Gelatinous zooplankton and colonial cnidarians with high consumption rates. Can dominate under eutrophic conditions. Moderate to high Q/B, influence energy flow by short-circuiting food webs.
High-value crustacean species targeted by fisheries. Low P/B, high economic importance. Often separated from ecologically similar non-commercial taxa for management purposes.
Economically important cephalopod species with high turnover and fishing pressure. High P/B and Q/B, short life cycles. Key components of artisanal and industrial fisheries.
Highly migratory, economically critical tuna species. High trophic level, subject to intense international fishing. Management-relevant due to stock declines and market value.
Benthic, nocturnal predators with elongated bodies. Occupy crevices and reefs, feeding on fish and invertebrates. Moderate P/B, important in reef food webs.
Benthic, camouflaged fish with low swimming activity. Feed on small invertebrates and fish. Moderate commercial value and distinct life history with larval pelagic phase.
Bottom-associated piscivorous fish with high trophic levels. Moderate P/B, important in controlling benthic prey populations. Some are commercially targeted.

Primary producers forming the base of the marine food web. Microscopic autotrophic organisms that convert sunlight into biomass through photosynthesis. High P/B ratio, short life cycle, and fundamental to energy input in the ecosystem.

Benthic primary producers including macroalgae and seagrasses. Provide habitat and food for herbivores, stabilize sediments, and contribute to coastal productivity. Moderate P/B, high structural role in shallow ecosystems.

Small heterotrophic organisms that consume phytoplankton and detritus. Key link between primary producers and higher trophic levels. High P/B and Q/B ratios, short generation times, and high turnover.
Dead organic matter from all trophic levels. Serves as a major energy source for decomposers and detritivores. Critical for nutrient cycling and microbial loop dynamics.

Small, schooling, planktivorous or omnivorous fish occupying mid-trophic levels. High P/B and Q/B ratios, fast growth, and high vulnerability to environmental variability and fishing. Key prey for larger predators.
Large, fast-swimming predatory fish that feed on fish and squid. High trophic level, moderate P/B, high Q/B, and apex predators in pelagic food webs. Highly migratory and vulnerable to overfishing.
Small pelagic species of high commercial value, often targeted in industrial fisheries. Ecologically similar to small pelagics but separated due to management and economic importance.
Midwater squid species with high turnover and important roles in vertical energy transfer. Prey for large pelagics and marine mammals. High Q/B and moderate P/B.

Bottom-associated fish inhabiting continental shelves, feeding on invertebrates and small fish. Moderate P/B and Q/B, important in benthic-pelagic coupling. Includes many commercially exploited species.
Demersal fish species of high commercial and cultural importance, often subject to intense fishing pressure. Separated for management and stock assessment purposes.
Fish inhabiting deep-sea benthic environments, often with slow growth, low P/B, and high vulnerability to trawling. Include seamount and slope specialists.
Pelagic sharks with high trophic levels, slow growth, and low P/B. Apex predators with high vulnerability to overfishing and bycatch. Regulate mid-trophic level populations.
Bottom-dwelling sharks and rays with low mobility, slow growth, and high sensitivity to habitat degradation and fishing. Include critically endangered species.
Benthic and reef-associated cephalopods with high metabolic rates, moderate P/B, and important as both predators and prey. Include commercially fished species.
Sessile and mobile invertebrates associated with rocky and reef habitats. Include filter feeders and grazers that structure benthic communities. Moderate to low P/B.
Crustacean species of high commercial value, often targeted in artisanal and industrial fisheries. Include lobsters and prawns with high economic importance.
Benthic invertebrates including sea urchins and starfish. Play key roles in grazing and predation on benthic communities. Moderate P/B and important in regulating algal cover.
Benthic segmented worms involved in bioturbation and detrital processing. High abundance and turnover, contribute to sediment health and nutrient cycling.
Gelatinous and sessile cnidarians including jellyfish and corals. Include both pelagic predators and benthic habitat formers. High Q/B in gelatinous forms, low P/B.
Apex predators with low P/B, long lifespans, and high trophic levels. Play roles in nutrient transport and top-down regulation. Highly vulnerable to anthropogenic impacts.
Marine birds that forage at sea, feeding on fish and squid. Link marine and terrestrial systems. Moderate P/B, high mobility, and sensitive to prey availability.
Early life stages of bony fish, often occupying nursery habitats. High mortality, high Q/B relative to biomass, and critical for recruitment dynamics.
Benthic, reef-associated eels with cryptic habits and predatory roles. Moderate P/B, occupy mesopredator niches in rocky and coral habitats.
