High trophic level, large-bodied, mobile predators that occupy top positions in pelagic food webs. They exhibit high Q/B ratios, low P/B ratios, and are vulnerable to overfishing. These species play key roles in energy transfer from lower trophic levels to apex consumers and are often of high commercial and cultural importance.

Medium to large-bodied, demersal or near-bottom predators that inhabit coastal and estuarine habitats. They are key in benthic-pelagic coupling, exhibit moderate to high Q/B ratios, and are often targeted by fisheries. These species are ecologically important for energy transfer and are frequently of commercial value.

Small to medium-sized, schooling fish that serve as critical prey for higher trophic levels. They have high P/B and Q/B ratios, are key in energy transfer from primary producers to predators, and are highly vulnerable to overfishing. These species are ecologically vital and often form the basis of commercial fisheries.

Predatory invertebrates that inhabit soft or hard substrates, feeding on smaller benthic organisms. They exhibit moderate to high Q/B ratios and play key roles in benthic food web dynamics, nutrient cycling, and energy transfer. Many are ecologically important but less targeted by fisheries.

Small to medium-sized organisms that feed on plankton and detritus in the water column. They have high P/B ratios and are key in transferring energy from primary producers to higher trophic levels. These species are ecologically important for nutrient cycling and are often sensitive to environmental change.

Primary consumers that graze on seagrasses, algae, and detritus in shallow coastal and estuarine habitats. They have moderate P/B ratios and play a critical role in benthic primary production control and nutrient cycling. These species are ecologically important but often overlooked in fisheries management.

Highly mobile, predatory cephalopods with high Q/B ratios and moderate P/B ratios. They occupy mid to high trophic levels, are key in energy transfer, and are ecologically important as both predators and prey. Many are commercially valuable and sensitive to environmental change.

Species with significant economic, cultural, or recreational value in fisheries and aquaculture. These taxa are often targeted, have high vulnerability to overfishing, and are central to management policies. They are separated from ecologically similar but non-commercial species to support targeted conservation and harvest strategies.

Species with broad diets, high plasticity in feeding behavior, and variable trophic positions. They occupy multiple trophic levels and are often resilient to environmental change. These species play key roles in energy redistribution and ecosystem stability, especially in disturbed or dynamic habitats.

Large, apex predatory elasmobranchs with high trophic levels, low P/B ratios, and significant ecological influence on food web structure. These species are vulnerable to overfishing and have slow life histories. Include both pelagic and coastal species.

Highly migratory, high trophic level predators with high Q/B ratios, significant biomass turnover, and key roles in pelagic energy transfer. Include commercially important species with high vulnerability to industrial fishing.

Medium-sized, benthic or nearshore predators with intermediate trophic levels, moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. These species are ecologically important in estuarine and coastal food webs and include both commercially valuable and ecologically significant taxa.

Small to medium-sized, planktivorous or omnivorous fish with high P/B ratios, rapid growth, and high turnover. These species are critical for energy transfer to higher trophic levels and are key prey for predators. Include both commercially and ecologically important species.

Medium to large benthic invertebrates with predatory or scavenging feeding habits, moderate to high P/B ratios, and key roles in benthic energy cycling. Include commercially important species and ecologically significant taxa.

Birds that feed primarily on small fish and zooplankton in pelagic or coastal zones. They occupy intermediate trophic levels, have high mobility, and serve as indicators of ecosystem health. Include both piscivorous and planktivorous species.

Large, apex avian predators with high trophic levels, low reproductive rates, and high sensitivity to environmental change. These species are ecologically significant and often serve as flagship species for conservation.

High trophic level, large-bodied marine mammals with low P/B ratios, long life spans, and high vulnerability to anthropogenic pressures. They play key roles in energy transfer and ecosystem regulation.

functional_groups.group_name: Estuarine and Coastal Herbivores and Detritivores
functional_groups.description: Small to medium-sized fish and invertebrates that consume seagrass, algae, or detritus. These species have high P/B ratios, contribute to nutrient cycling, and are foundational in estuarine food webs.

Small, pelagic invertebrates (e.g., crustaceans, cephalopods) with high P/B and Q/B ratios, serving as critical links between primary producers and higher trophic levels. Include both larval stages and adult planktonic forms.

Small to medium-sized reef-associated fish with diverse feeding strategies (herbivory, omnivory, planktivory) that contribute to reef resilience and biodiversity. These species are ecologically important but not typically targeted by commercial fisheries.

Species with significant economic value in fisheries and aquaculture. These taxa are often overexploited and require targeted management. Grouped separately to enable assessment of fishery impacts and sustainability.

High trophic level, mobile predators with high Q/B and low P/B ratios; primarily piscivorous, occupying top positions in pelagic food webs; include large sharks, tunas, and billfishes; highly vulnerable to overfishing and environmental change.

Medium to large-bodied, demersal or near-bottom predators with moderate to high P/B ratios; include coastal sharks, rays, and large benthic fish; play key roles in energy transfer from benthic to pelagic zones; vulnerable to habitat degradation and fishing pressure.

functional_groups.group_name: Small Pelagic Fish and Forage Species
functional_groups.description: Small, schooling fish with high P/B and high Q/B ratios; serve as critical energy transfer agents between primary producers and higher trophic levels; highly sensitive to environmental variability and overfishing; include anchovies, sardines, and menhaden.

Organisms that consume benthic invertebrates, detritus, or organic matter; include small to medium-sized fish and invertebrates with moderate P/B ratios; play key roles in nutrient cycling and benthic-pelagic coupling.
Predators of benthic invertebrates such as crustaceans, mollusks, and echinoderms; include crabs, lobsters, and some fish; exhibit moderate P/B ratios and are key in benthic food web dynamics.
Fish species associated with pelagic or reef habitats; include surface and mid-water feeders with moderate to high P/B ratios; contribute to energy transfer and habitat-specific food web dynamics.

Small-bodied, high-turnover organisms including zooplankton, small crustaceans, and small mollusks; serve as primary consumers and key prey for forage fish and invertebrate predators; high P/B ratios and rapid life cycles.

Species of high economic or cultural value, including commercially harvested fish, shellfish, and marine mammals; often targeted by fisheries and subject to management regulations; include both ecologically and economically significant taxa.

Organisms that form the base of the food web, including phytoplankton, macroalgae, and detritivores; include filter feeders and deposit feeders with low to moderate P/B ratios; critical for energy input and nutrient recycling.
Large predatory sharks and rays that occupy the top trophic level in marine ecosystems, playing a crucial role in maintaining ecosystem balance.
Birds that primarily feed on fish and other marine organisms, acting as apex predators in coastal ecosystems.
Large marine mammals that feed on fish, squid, and other marine organisms, playing a key role in nutrient cycling and ecosystem structure.
Active swimmers in the pelagic zone, feeding on smaller fish, squid, and plankton, serving as a crucial link in marine food webs.
Fish and invertebrates that primarily feed on benthic organisms, playing a key role in controlling benthic community structure.
Small fish that are often prey for larger predators, forming the base of many marine food webs.
Sharks and rays that frequent coastal waters, feeding on a variety of benthic and pelagic prey.
Filter-feeding mollusks that play a key role in water filtration and benthic-pelagic coupling.
Predatory and grazing snails that contribute to benthic community dynamics.
Highly mobile predators feeding on fish, crustaceans, and other cephalopods, playing a key role in pelagic ecosystems.
Crabs, shrimps, and lobsters that are key components of benthic and pelagic ecosystems, serving as both predators and prey.
Predatory crustaceans that play a role in controlling populations of smaller invertebrates.
Filter-feeding organisms that contribute to planktonic and benthic ecosystems.
Segmented worms that play a role in sediment turnover and nutrient cycling.
Key benthic organisms involved in predator-prey dynamics and ecosystem engineering.
Small crustaceans that are important grazers and prey items in marine ecosystems.
Diverse group of crustaceans with roles ranging from detritivory to predation.
Crabs, shrimps, and lobsters that are key components of benthic and pelagic ecosystems.
Apex predators in the pelagic environment, feeding on fish and squid.
Top predators with varied habitats, including pelagic and benthic environments.
Top predators feeding on fish and squid, ecologically significant.
Birds with various feeding strategies in marine environments.
Fish primarily inhabiting the benthic zone, including predators and grazers.
Schooling fish often serving as forage species.
Important invertebrate predators in the pelagic zone.
Includes crabs, shrimp, and lobsters, key in benthic and pelagic ecosystems.
Filter-feeding mollusks important in water filtration.
Apex predators including sharks and rays that feed on fish, squid, and other marine animals. They play a crucial role in maintaining the balance of marine ecosystems.
Birds that feed on fish, squid, and other marine organisms. They are important indicators of marine ecosystem health.
Crustaceans and other benthic organisms that feed on detritus, algae, or small animals. They are key components of the benthic food web.
Highly migratory, commercially important fish that feed on smaller fish and squid. They are crucial for both the ecosystem and fisheries.
Important predators in coastal ecosystems, feeding on fish and invertebrates. They are often targeted in commercial fisheries.
Schooling fish that feed on plankton and small organisms. They form the base of many marine food webs.
Fish and invertebrates that feed on benthic organisms, playing a role in nutrient cycling.
Fish that inhabit coral reefs and adjacent areas, contributing to reef biodiversity.
Fish that live near the seafloor, feeding on benthic organisms. They are important in demersal ecosystems.
Fish that feed on plankton, serving as a link between primary producers and higher trophic levels.
Organisms that filter-feed on plankton and detritus, important for water quality and habitat creation.
Active, bottom-dwelling organisms that feed on small animals and detritus. They contribute to benthic productivity.
A diverse group of invertebrates with various ecological roles, including predation and detritivory.
Large raptorial birds that feed primarily on fish; high trophic level, occupy coastal and inland water habitats; culturally important species with low P/B and Q/B ratios.
Generalist seabirds that exploit pelagic and near‑shore resources; omnivorous to piscivorous, moderate life‑history speed, important scavengers and predators of eggs and larvae.
Highly mobile, top‑level predators that feed on fish and squid; fast life histories, high Q/B, sensitive to by‑catch and acoustic disturbance.
Apex elasmobranch predators occupying open‑water habitats; long‑lived, low P/B, low Q/B, vulnerable to over‑fishing and habitat loss.
Demersal cartilaginous fishes that feed on benthic invertebrates and small fishes; moderate life‑history speed, important for benthic energy flow.
Highly migratory, high‑trophic‑level pelagic predator; fast growth, high market value, heavily targeted by fisheries.
Fast‑growing, pelagic predator with high Q/B; important for both commercial and sport fisheries.
Large pelagic predator, high trophic level, fast life history, valuable sport and commercial species.
Mid‑size pelagic predator, high turnover, important for coastal fisheries.
Robust pelagic/near‑shore predator, moderate longevity, high catch rates in mixed‑gear fisheries.
Small‑to‑medium pelagic predator, fast growth, often caught as by‑catch in tuna and shrimp fisheries.
Small pelagic predator, high reproductive output, targeted in coastal purse‑seine fisheries.
Fast‑growing, coastal pelagic predator; high market value, cultured and wild‑caught.
Large, fast‑swimming pelagic predator; prized sport fish with moderate commercial landings.
Large demersal predators on reefs and hardbottoms; long‑lived, low P/B, high economic importance.
Mid‑trophic demersal predators associated with reef and offshore habitats; moderate growth rates, high market demand.
Benthic/near‑benthic predators and opportunistic feeders; moderate life histories, important for coastal fisheries.
Flat, demersal predators on soft substrates; relatively fast turnover, valued in both fresh and frozen markets.
Fast‑growing, near‑shore demersal predators; high price per unit weight, targeted by gill‑net and hook‑and‑line gear.
Benthic omnivores with high reproductive rates; short life span, heavily harvested for bait and food markets.
Key pelagic forage fish with very high reproductive output; low trophic level, supports large fisheries for fishmeal and bait.
Benthic decapods with high market value; relatively short life cycles (crabs) to longer‑lived lobsters; important for benthic energy transfer.
Small pelagic/nektonic crustaceans with high turnover; high Q/B, heavily exploited by trawl and seine fisheries.
Fast‑growing cephalopods that feed on fish and crustaceans; high Q/B, important for both direct human consumption and as prey for higher predators.
Sessile filter‑feeding invertebrates that convert planktonic production into benthic biomass; high P/B, low Q/B, provide habitat complexity.
Short‑lived, high‑turnover species that dominate the lower pelagic food web; essential prey for many predators, low direct fishery value.
Mid‑trophic nekton that feed on fish and crustaceans; fast life histories, important prey for dolphins and sharks.
Diverse sessile and mobile invertebrates (anemones, echinoderms, annelids, amphipods, isopods) that recycle detritus and provide prey for higher trophic levels.
Large pelagic and semi‑pelagic shark species that act as top predators in the open ocean, with high trophic level, low P/B, and low direct fishing pressure in this model.
Highly valuable, fast‑growing, apex pelagic predators with high Q/B, targeted by industrial fisheries.
Fast‑swimming, mid‑to‑high trophic level pelagic fishes (jacks, mackerels, cobia, bluefish) supporting major commercial fisheries.
Bottom‑associated, moderate‑size predatory and opportunistic fishes (snappers, groupers, drums, flounders, grunts, sheepshead) that are key targets of coastal fisheries.
Small, fast‑reproducing pelagic species (menhaden, anchovies, sardines, herring, mullets) that provide a major energy pathway to higher trophic levels and support large‑scale forage fisheries.
High‑value benthic and demersal crustaceans (blue crab, spiny lobster, shrimp, mantis shrimp) with relatively high P/B and strong fishery exploitation.
Sessile filter‑feeding mollusks harvested for human consumption; low trophic level, high P/B, and important for benthic nutrient cycling.
Highly mobile marine mammals that occupy the highest trophic level in the pelagic food web, with low direct fishing mortality.
Demersal elasmobranchs (skates, stingrays, guitarfish) that prey on benthic invertebrates and small fishes, linking benthic and pelagic pathways.
Fast‑growing, short‑lived squid species that feed on small fishes and crustaceans, providing an important mid‑trophic link.
Large piscivorous birds (eagles, osprey, loons, gannets) that forage primarily on fish and serve as indicators of ecosystem health.
Colonial, surface‑feeding seabirds that exploit pelagic and near‑shore fish resources; moderate trophic level and relatively low direct harvest.
Large colonial waterbirds that feed on fish and squid; occupy intermediate trophic positions and are important for nutrient transport between marine and terrestrial systems.
Highly mobile marine mammals that feed on mid‑trophic fish and squid, representing the highest trophic level in the pelagic compartment.
Bottom‑dwelling elasmobranchs that prey on invertebrates and small fishes; moderate trophic level with low P/B and limited commercial exploitation.
Short‑lived, high‑growth‑rate squid species that occupy mid‑trophic levels, linking lower trophic prey to higher predators.
Sessile and mobile benthic invertebrates (tunicata, polychaetes, echinoderms, amphipods, isopods, etc.) that recycle organic matter and provide food for higher trophic levels.
Small, low‑trophic‑level fishes inhabiting estuarine or freshwater habitats; low economic value and high P/B.
Cultural emblem and top avian predator; large-bodied, low reproductive rate, primarily coastal and riverine habitats; feeds on fish and carrion; low P/B, high vulnerability to disturbance.
Culturally important fish‑eating raptor; medium‑large, piscivorous, nests near water; high trophic level, moderate P/B, sensitive to water quality.
Gulls, terns and related seabirds that forage in the water column; opportunistic predators and scavengers; moderate body size, high mobility, important link between marine and terrestrial systems.
Highly mobile, top marine predators; fast life histories, high metabolic rates, strong influence on pelagic food webs; vulnerable to by‑catch and acoustic disturbance.
Apex coastal shark; large-bodied, euryhaline, high trophic level; high Q/B, heavily targeted by fisheries; vulnerable to over‑exploitation.
Coastal pelagic predator; fast growth, high turnover; important for near‑shore fisheries.
Mid‑size coastal shark; moderate longevity, high catchability; contributes to pelagic‑benthic energy flow.
Highly migratory, pelagic shark; high production relative to biomass; targeted in pelagic long‑line fisheries.
Small coastal shark; rapid turnover, high P/B; important for inshore demersal catches.
Small, fast‑growing shark of estuarine and near‑shore waters; high Q/B, heavily fished.
Small hammerhead inhabiting shallow coastal habitats; high reproductive output, subject to artisanal fisheries.
Large benthopelagic predators (S. lewini, S. mokarran, S. zygaena); long‑lived, low P/B, low direct fishing pressure in the region.
Includes tiger shark, silky shark, nurse shark, and various stingrays; generally lower commercial value, important top predators in reef and continental‑shelf ecosystems.
Large, highly migratory pelagic predator; fast growth, high Q/B; major target of industrial tuna fisheries.
Very large, long‑lived apex predator; low P/B, high economic value; subject to intense management scrutiny.
Medium‑size scombrid; high turnover, important for coastal purse‑seine fisheries.
Fast, pelagic predator prized in sport fisheries; high growth rate, moderate P/B.
Large, coastal‑pelagic predator; rapid growth, high market value; supports both commercial and recreational fisheries.
Fast‑swimming, pelagic predator; high Q/B, important for offshore hook‑and‑line fisheries.
Smaller pelagic scombrid; high reproductive output, targeted by coastal fisheries.
Mid‑size pelagic fish; moderate growth, supports small‑scale fisheries.
Robust, coastal‑pelagic predator; high catch rates in mixed‑gear fisheries.
Small, fast‑growing jack; high turnover, important forage for larger predators.
Demersal predator of continental shelf; moderate longevity, high market demand.
Key demersal fishery species; long‑lived, high economic value, subject to strict management.
Smaller snapper; fast growth, important for artisanal fisheries.
Large, reef‑associated predators (Epinephelus spp., Mycteroperca spp.); long life spans, low P/B, high commercial value.
Demersal predator of estuarine and near‑shore habitats; moderate growth, high market demand.
Coastal demersal predators; rapid turnover, support both commercial and recreational fisheries.
Benthic forager; high reproductive output, important in mixed‑species demersal catches.
Large, bottom‑dwelling predator; long life, low P/B, high price in regional markets.
Flatfish occupying soft‑bottom habitats; fast growth, high catchability in trawl fisheries.
Small coastal catfishes; high reproductive rates, important for near‑shore gill‑net fisheries.
Euryhaline, coastal‑estuarine fish; rapid turnover, widely harvested for food and bait.
Mid‑trophic, schooling species that provide a major energy pathway to higher predators; high P/B, heavily fished for fishmeal and bait.
Species such as pompano, sheepshead, spadefish, and pinfish; moderate size, high growth rates, support local markets and provide prey for larger predators.
Tetraodontidae spp.; small, slow‑moving benthic foragers with toxic tissues; harvested in small‑scale fisheries.
Key crustacean resources; high turnover, short life cycles, support both industrial trawl and artisanal gear fisheries.
Highly valuable, estuarine crab; moderate longevity, high catch per unit effort, vulnerable to habitat loss.
Benthic crab harvested for its roe; relatively long‑lived, low P/B, subject to seasonal closures.
Large reef‑associated crustaceans; slow growth, low P/B, high market price; heavily managed.
Sessile bivalve forming reef habitats; high filtration rates, moderate P/B, important for water quality and fisheries.
Bivalve and gastropod species harvested for food; short life cycles, high production relative to biomass.
Fast‑growing cephalopods (Lolliguncula brevis, Doryteuthis pealeii, Loligo plei); high Q/B, important for both direct harvest and as prey for higher predators.
Echinoderms, annelids, amphipods, isopods, tunicates, and sea anemones; low trophic level, high P/B, provide habitat complexity and serve as prey for many fish and crustaceans.
Short‑lived, high‑turnover small fishes (Menidia spp., Leiostomus xanthurus, Micropogonias undulatus, etc.) that dominate the lower pelagic and near‑shore food web.

Large avian predators occupying the highest trophic levels, primarily piscivorous with high mobility and low P/B ratios. These species forage in pelagic and coastal zones and are sensitive to bioaccumulation of contaminants. Include bald eagle and osprey, which have high cultural and conservation value.

Pursuit-diving birds that feed on mid-water fish and invertebrates. They occupy mid-to-upper trophic levels, associate with pelagic and nearshore habitats, and have moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. Play key role in transferring marine productivity to coastal ecosystems.

Small to medium-sized aerial foragers that feed on surface-schooling fish and invertebrates. High P/B and mobility, low to mid trophic level. Often colonial, associated with coastal and estuarine habitats. Important for nutrient cycling and as indicators of forage fish abundance.

Large surface-foraging and kleptoparasitic seabirds with broad diets including fish and squid. Occupy mid-to-high trophic levels, associated with offshore and coastal waters. Low P/B, high mobility. Frigatebirds are aerial specialists; pelicans use plunge-diving.

Small cetaceans occupying high trophic levels, feeding on fish and squid. Moderate P/B, long-lived, low reproductive rates. Prefer coastal and estuarine habitats. Highly vulnerable to bycatch and habitat degradation. Social and long-ranging.

Apex predatory sharks with high trophic positions, feeding on fish, rays, and marine mammals. Low P/B, slow growth, late maturity. Found in coastal and shelf waters. Highly vulnerable to fishing pressure. Include species of significant conservation concern.

Mid-level predatory sharks with moderate trophic levels, feeding on fish and invertebrates. Higher P/B than large sharks, faster life histories. Common in nearshore and estuarine environments. Important mesopredators and prey for larger sharks.

Benthic and demersal elasmobranchs feeding on invertebrates and small fish. Low to mid trophic levels, moderate P/B. Found in soft-bottom habitats from estuaries to shelf waters. Vulnerable to bottom fishing and habitat loss.

Fast-swimming, high-trophic-level predators such as jacks, groupers, and large snappers. High Q/B, moderate P/B. Occupy pelagic and reef-associated habitats. Many are long-lived and vulnerable to overfishing. Include commercially and culturally important species.

Small to medium-sized demersal and pelagic fish with high P/B and Q/B ratios. Feed on invertebrates and small fish. Found in estuarine, nearshore, and reef habitats. Serve as key forage for larger predators. Include species with high turnover and resilience.

Small pelagic fish forming dense schools, feeding on plankton. High P/B and Q/B, short life spans. Critical energy link between lower trophic levels and higher predators. Highly vulnerable to environmental variability and fishing. Include ecologically and commercially significant species.

Small fish with limited commercial value but high ecological importance as prey. Include killifish and livebearers in estuarine and marsh habitats. High P/B, short life cycles. Important in nutrient cycling and as indicators of habitat health.

Fast-growing, high-turnover invertebrate predators with high Q/B and P/B. Feed on fish and crustaceans, serve as prey for fish, birds, and mammals. Occupy mid-to-high trophic levels. Highly responsive to environmental change and fishing pressure.

Demersal and estuarine crustaceans with high P/B, omnivorous or detritivorous feeding. Key prey for fish and birds. Include commercially important penaeids. Found in soft-bottom and vegetated habitats. Vulnerable to trawling and habitat degradation.

Benthic decapods with moderate P/B, omnivorous or predatory diets. Include ecologically and commercially important species. Found in reef, soft-bottom, and estuarine habitats. Play roles in bioturbation and as prey.

Specialized benthic crustaceans with predatory or scavenging habits. Moderate biomass turnover. Found in burrows and reef crevices. Contribute to benthic community dynamics and serve as prey for larger fish.

Sessile, filter-feeding bivalves with high ecosystem engineering impact. Low P/B but high biomass. Form reefs that provide habitat and improve water quality. Highly vulnerable to overharvest and disease.

Benthic mollusks feeding on algae, detritus, or other invertebrates. Moderate P/B, important in nutrient cycling and as prey. Found in soft-bottom and hard-substrate habitats. Include herbivores and scavengers.

Filter-feeding colonial or solitary invertebrates with high filtration capacity. Low trophic level, contribute to benthic-pelagic coupling. Found in hard-bottom and artificial habitats. Can be dominant space competitors.

Sessile or slow-moving benthic predators and filter feeders. Include cnidarians and annelids. Occupy low to mid trophic levels. Provide microhabitat and serve as prey. Sensitive to sedimentation and pollution.
Small mobile benthic crustaceans with high P/B, detritivorous or omnivorous diets. Key in decomposition and nutrient recycling. Found in sediments and vegetation. Important prey for fish and birds.

Benthic invertebrates including sea stars and urchins. Moderate P/B, feed on detritus, algae, or invertebrates. Play roles in bioturbation and community regulation. Sensitive to environmental stressors.
Ancient fish with slow life histories, benthic-pelagic transition feeders. Low P/B, long-lived. Found in brackish and freshwater-influenced habitats. Low commercial value but ecologically unique.
Benthic, omnivorous fish with moderate P/B. Feed on detritus and invertebrates. Found in soft-bottom and estuarine habitats. Tolerant of low oxygen, serve as scavengers and prey.

Euryhaline, detritivorous fish with high P/B. Feed on microalgae and organic matter in sediments. Found in estuaries and coastal waters. Important in energy transfer from detritus to higher trophic levels.
Small to medium fish with specialized diets, including hard-shelled invertebrates. Moderate P/B. Found in reef and soft-bottom habitats. Include species with defensive adaptations.
Broad group of crustaceans not otherwise classified. Include scavengers and omnivores. Contribute to benthic community dynamics and serve as prey.

Large piscivorous and scavenging birds occupying the highest trophic levels. These are aerial predators that feed on fish and occasionally scavenge, with low P/B ratios and high trophic positions. They utilize coastal, pelagic, and estuarine habitats and are sensitive to environmental contaminants and habitat disturbance.

Pursuit-diving birds that forage underwater, primarily feeding on mid-sized pelagic and coastal fish. They have moderate P/B and Q/B ratios, occupy mid-to-high trophic levels, and link pelagic production to top predators. Sensitive to fishery declines and oil spills.

Small to medium-sized seabirds that feed on or near the water surface, consuming small fish, invertebrates, and plankton. High P/B ratios, colonial breeders, and important in energy transfer from lower trophic levels. Include terns, gulls, skimmers, and noddies with high mobility and opportunistic feeding.

High-trophic-level, large-bodied fish with high mobility, including tunas, billfish, and large sharks. High consumption rates (Q/B), moderate P/B, and key in transferring energy across oceanic ecosystems. Highly migratory and vulnerable to overfishing. Include species of major commercial and cultural importance.

Medium-sized predatory fish inhabiting coastal and shelf waters, feeding on forage fish and invertebrates. Moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. Important in linking lower trophic levels to larger predators. Some species are commercially targeted.

Serranids and lutjanids associated with reef and hard-bottom habitats. Medium to large body size, moderate P/B, and high trophic positions. Include ecologically and commercially important species. Vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation.

Apex predatory sharks with high trophic levels, low P/B ratios, and slow life histories. Found in coastal and shelf ecosystems. Highly vulnerable to fishing pressure and play critical roles in regulating prey populations.

Smaller elasmobranchs with benthic or demersal habits, feeding on invertebrates and small fish. Moderate to low P/B, occupy mid-trophic levels. Include species with varying vulnerability to bycatch and habitat loss.

Bottom-associated fish feeding on benthic invertebrates and small fish. Moderate P/B and Q/B, important in benthic-pelagic coupling. Include species with commercial value and moderate vulnerability to trawling.

Small, schooling fish that form the base of pelagic food webs. High P/B and Q/B ratios, short lifespans, and high productivity. Serve as key prey for larger fish, birds, and marine mammals. Include ecologically critical but often under-monitored species.

Small to medium-sized fish inhabiting estuaries, seagrass beds, and shallow coastal zones. Feed on invertebrates and detritus. Moderate P/B, important as nursery species and prey. Include both generalists and specialists.

Large-bodied fish with low P/B ratios and long life spans, not typically targeted by fisheries. Play roles as apex or mesopredators in specific habitats. Include gar and billfish relatives with low resilience to disturbance.

Economically important decapods with high cultural and market value. Occupy benthic habitats, serve as mid-level predators and scavengers. Moderate P/B, vulnerable to overharvesting and habitat loss. Key for fisheries management.

Benthic decapods and other crustaceans not directly targeted by fisheries. Include shrimp, amphipods, isopods, and stomatopods. High abundance, moderate to high P/B, and critical in nutrient cycling and as prey.

Sessile or sedentary filter feeders that regulate water quality and form biogenic habitats. High P/B when abundant, low mobility, and sensitive to pollution and hypoxia. Include oysters and other bivalves crucial for ecosystem engineering.

Soft-bodied benthic invertebrates feeding on detritus, algae, or other invertebrates. Moderate P/B, important in benthic food webs and sediment dynamics. Include grazers and scavengers with roles in nutrient recycling.

Small fish and early life stages that serve as critical prey for higher trophic levels. High P/B and turnover rates. Include species from Cyprinodontidae, Poeciliidae, and Menidia spp. that inhabit shallow, vegetated areas.

Free-swimming invertebrates including squid and larval stages. High Q/B and P/B, occupy mid-trophic levels, and serve as prey for fish, birds, and marine mammals. Important in vertical energy transfer.

Benthic invertebrates including sea stars, urchins, and others. Moderate P/B, play roles in bioturbation and predation on bivalves. Sensitive to ocean acidification and disease, with regulatory roles in benthic communities.

Sessile or semi-sessile invertebrates such as sea anemones. Low mobility, feed on plankton and detritus. Contribute to habitat complexity and serve as prey or hosts. Include benthic cnidarians in soft and hard substrates.

Large piscivorous and scavenging birds occupying the highest trophic levels. These are aerial predators that feed on fish and occasionally scavenge, with low P/B and Q/B ratios due to large body size and slow life histories. Key species include raptors with high site fidelity and sensitivity to environmental contaminants.

Pursuit-diving birds that forage underwater, primarily feeding on mid-trophic level fish. They exhibit moderate P/B and high Q/B ratios, reflecting active foraging and high metabolic demands. Associated with pelagic and nearshore habitats.

Small to medium-sized aerial foragers that plunge-dive or skim the water surface to capture small fish. High P/B and Q/B ratios due to fast life histories and high energy demands. Occupy coastal, estuarine, and pelagic zones; important for nutrient cycling and as indicators of forage fish abundance.

Opportunistic omnivorous birds with broad diets including fish, invertebrates, and scavenged material. Moderate P/B and high Q/B ratios. Utilize coastal, benthic, and human-impacted environments. High adaptability and resilience to disturbance.

Large pelagic seabirds that engage in kleptoparasitism (frigatebird) or plunge-diving (pelicans). Occupy offshore and coastal zones. Low P/B ratios due to large body size and K-selected life histories. Play key roles in cross-habitat energy transfer.

High trophic-level marine mammals that prey on fish and squid. Long-lived, social, with low P/B ratios and high site fidelity. Sensitive to habitat degradation and bycatch. Key apex consumers in coastal and shelf ecosystems.

Apex predatory sharks with high trophic positions, slow growth, low fecundity, and high vulnerability to fishing. Occupy pelagic and epipelagic zones. Low P/B and Q/B ratios. Critical for regulating mid-trophic level populations.

Medium-sized sharks inhabiting coastal, estuarine, and shelf environments. Feed on fish and benthic invertebrates. Moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. Include species of high commercial and recreational value with moderate to high fishing vulnerability.

Benthic elasmobranchs that feed on invertebrates and small fish. Low to moderate P/B ratios, demersal lifestyle, and high sensitivity to bottom fishing. Play important roles in benthic-pelagic coupling.

Fast-swimming, high-trophic-level fish including tunas, mackerels, and billfish analogs. High metabolic rates, high Q/B, and moderate P/B. Key components of offshore food webs and major targets of commercial and recreational fisheries.

Reef- and coastal-associated predatory fish with varied diets. Include species of high commercial and recreational importance. Moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. Serve as mesopredators linking lower trophic levels to apex consumers.

Demersal and benthic-associated fish that feed on invertebrates and smaller fish. Occupy estuaries, seagrass beds, and nearshore habitats. Moderate P/B and Q/B. Include ecologically important and commercially targeted species.

Benthic fish with cryptic morphology and feeding behavior. Feed on benthic invertebrates and small fish. Low to moderate P/B ratios. Important in sediment-dwelling food webs and vulnerable to trawling.

Ancient fish lineages with slow growth and low reproductive rates. Benthic to mid-water predators in estuarine and freshwater-influenced habitats. Low P/B ratios and high resilience to hypoxia. Play unique roles in food web stability.

Detritivorous and omnivorous fish that feed on organic matter and benthic invertebrates. High abundance in estuaries. Moderate to high P/B ratios. Important in nutrient cycling and as prey for larger predators.

Small to medium-sized fish associated with reefs, rocks, or structured habitats. Feed on invertebrates and algae. Include ecologically important mesopredators and prey species. Moderate turnover rates.
Elongated, pelagic predators that feed on small fish. Occupy surface to mid-water zones. High Q/B due to active foraging. Serve as mid-trophic level consumers and prey for larger fish and birds.

High-turnover, schooling fish that form the base of pelagic food webs. High P/B and Q/B ratios. Critical prey for piscivores, seabirds, and marine mammals. Sensitive to environmental variability and fishing pressure.

Small-bodied, short-lived fish with high reproductive output. Include killifish and livebearers. Occupy shallow, vegetated, and brackish habitats. High P/B ratios. Important in nutrient cycling and as prey, but not targeted by fisheries.

Fast-growing, short-lived mollusks with high metabolic and predation rates. Occupy pelagic and benthic zones. High P/B and Q/B ratios. Serve as key prey and predators, linking different trophic pathways.
Decapod crustaceans with high turnover rates. Benthic and pelagic forms. Important as prey and detritivores. High P/B and Q/B. Include commercially valuable species.
Benthic crustaceans of high commercial value. Moderate P/B ratios, omnivorous or scavenging diets. Key in benthic food webs and economically significant. Vulnerable to overfishing.
Large, long-lived benthic crustaceans with high commercial value. Low P/B ratios, reef- or structure-associated. Important in benthic energy transfer and highly vulnerable to exploitation.
Aggressive benthic predators with high feeding rates. Contribute to invertebrate predation and sediment turnover. Not commercially targeted but ecologically significant.
Diverse group including stomatopods and other benthic arthropods. Feed on invertebrates and detritus. Moderate to high Q/B. Support higher trophic levels.
Sessile and slow-moving invertebrates including mollusks and echinoderms. Filter feeders and detritivores. Low P/B, high biomass. Foundation of benthic food webs.
Sessile bivalves that filter plankton and organic particles. Form reefs and provide habitat. Low P/B, high ecosystem value. Include species of commercial and restoration interest.
Segmented worms that inhabit sediments. Feed on detritus and microorganisms. High abundance and turnover. Key in nutrient cycling and benthic-pelagic coupling.
Gelatinous predators with boom-bust population dynamics. Feed on zooplankton and small fish. Can dominate food webs under certain conditions. High Q/B during blooms.

functional_groups.description: Includes primary producers (phytoplankton) and filter-feeding organisms that occupy the base of the pelagic food web.  Characterized by small size, high biomass, and significant role in energy transfer.  Vulnerable to ocean acidification and pollution.

Predatory organisms inhabiting the open ocean, feeding on plankton, fish, and other marine life.  Important for regulating plankton populations and energy flow.  Often long-lived and have high mobility.  Vulnerable to overfishing and bycatch.

Organisms inhabiting coral reefs, rocky shores, and the seabed.  Diverse feeding strategies, including grazing, predation, and detritivory.  Important for reef ecosystem health and nutrient cycling.  Vulnerable to habitat destruction and pollution.

Organisms that feed on algae, seagrass, or detritus.  Important for maintaining ecosystem balance and nutrient cycling.  Often have specialized feeding adaptations.  Vulnerable to habitat loss and pollution.
Fish species with significant economic value due to their consumption by humans.  Often highly regulated to prevent overfishing.  Vulnerable to habitat degradation and climate change.

Organisms inhabiting the deep ocean floor.  Often adapted to high pressure, low light, and limited food availability.  Important for deep-sea ecosystem function.  Vulnerable to deep-sea mining and pollution.

functional_groups.description: Top predators occupying high trophic levels, primarily marine carnivores with diverse habitats including pelagic and benthic zones.
Mid-trophic level fish associated with coral reefs, including herbivores and carnivores that play key roles in maintaining reef ecosystems.
High-trophic level fish occupying open water habitats, primarily apex predators that regulate pelagic ecosystems.
Carnivorous rays and skates that primarily feed on the ocean floor, contributing to benthic ecosystem regulation.
Small, high-abundance fish that form the base of higher trophic levels in marine food webs, often preyed upon by larger predators.
Larger species of rays that may have unique ecological roles, including filter feeding and benthic foraging.
Sharks with significant commercial value, often targeted by fisheries, requiring separate management considerations.
Diverse group of marine invertebrates with varied ecological roles, including benthic predation and scavenging.
High trophic level predators with significant ecological roles; includes sharks and rays.
Large, fast-swimming predators in the pelagic zone; includes tunas and billfish.
Predators primarily feeding on fish; includes barracudas and jacks.
Fish species associated with coral reefs, including groupers and snappers.
Small fish that serve as prey for larger predators; includes mullets and pompanos.
Fish that feed on plankton; includes small pelagic species.
Fish and invertebrates feeding on the ocean floor; includes shrimp and crabs.
Squid and octopus, important as both predators and prey in the food web.
Invertebrates with unique ecological roles; includes stomatopods and holothurians.
Culturally significant apex predators with unique ecological roles.
Large sharks, dolphins, and other top predators with significant ecological influence.
Sharks that occupy the open ocean, including requiem sharks and others.
Bottom-dwelling rays, skates, and related species with benthic feeding habits.
Carnivorous fish that inhabit coral reefs and adjacent habitats.
Small, planktivorous fish that form the base of higher trophic levels.
Highly migratory, open-ocean predators with significant ecological and commercial importance.
Highly specialized predators with unique morphological adaptations for speed and predation.
Fish that primarily feed on other fish and invertebrates within reef ecosystems.
Invertebrates that inhabit the seafloor and play crucial roles in nutrient cycling.
Species of high cultural or commercial importance that warrant separate consideration.

High trophic level, mobile predators with high P/B and Q/B ratios; primarily epipelagic, feeding on mid-sized fish and squid; include commercially important species and apex predators. Key ecological role: top-down control of mesopredator populations and energy transfer to higher trophic levels.

Mid-trophic level, schooling fish with moderate P/B and Q/B ratios; pelagic or near-surface habitat use; important in energy transfer from lower trophic levels to larger predators. Include both commercially important and ecologically significant species.

Predators inhabiting coral or rocky reefs with moderate to high P/B; feed on invertebrates and small fish; contribute to reef trophic dynamics and control of invertebrate populations. Include both ecologically and commercially important species.
Primary consumers and detritivores on reefs; low to moderate P/B; play key roles in algal control and nutrient cycling; include ecologically vital but often non-commercial species.
Bottom-dwelling predators with moderate P/B; feed on invertebrates and small fish; occupy sandy, muddy, or seagrass habitats; important in benthic energy transfer and benthic-pelagic coupling.
Low trophic level, benthic organisms with low P/B; consume detritus, meiofauna, and benthic invertebrates; critical for nutrient recycling and sediment turnover in soft-bottom habitats.

Highly targeted species with significant economic value; often large-bodied, high Q/B, and key to fisheries; include major tuna, billfish, and mackerel species. Their removal can disrupt pelagic food webs.
High-value reef fish species with significant fisheries and cultural importance; include groupers, snappers, and other high-trophic-level species; often slow-growing and vulnerable to overfishing.

Low to mid-trophic level, small schooling fish with high P/B and Q/B; feed on plankton; serve as critical energy transfer agents between primary producers and higher trophic levels; ecologically vital but often overlooked in management.
Predators and scavengers of benthic invertebrates; moderate P/B; contribute to benthic food web dynamics and nutrient cycling; include crustaceans, cephalopods, and some fish.
Small, benthic organisms that consume detritus and microfauna in seagrass and soft-bottom habitats; low P/B; play key roles in organic matter decomposition and nutrient recycling.

High trophic level, large-bodied, mobile predators in the open ocean; primarily piscivorous with high Q/B and low P/B ratios; key apex predators in pelagic food webs; include commercially important species such as tunas and billfishes. Vulnerable to overfishing due to slow growth and late maturity.

Small, schooling fish with high P/B and Q/B ratios; key intermediates in pelagic energy transfer; serve as prey for larger predators; include major commercial species such as sardines and anchovies. Highly vulnerable to overfishing due to high exploitation rates and low resilience.

Medium to large benthic invertebrates with high consumption rates (Q/B) and moderate P/B; primarily carnivorous, feeding on smaller invertebrates; play key roles in benthic energy transfer and nutrient cycling; include commercially important species such as spiny lobsters and crabs.

Small to medium-sized reef-dwelling fish with moderate P/B and Q/B; occupy intermediate trophic levels; contribute to reef biodiversity and energy transfer; include herbivores, omnivores, and small predators; ecologically important but not targeted by major fisheries.

High-value, targeted invertebrates with low to moderate P/B ratios; include species with high economic and cultural significance; often harvested at high rates; vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation; include spiny lobster, shrimp, and crabs.

Small to medium-sized benthic invertebrates that consume organic detritus; play critical roles in nutrient recycling and sediment turnover; have high P/B ratios and low Q/B; form the base of benthic food webs; include polychaetes, amphipods, and certain bivalves.

Small, pelagic fish and invertebrates that feed primarily on plankton; occupy intermediate trophic levels; have high P/B and Q/B ratios; serve as key links between primary producers and higher trophic levels; include small forage fish and zooplanktivores.

High trophic level, apex predators in the pelagic zone; include large sharks, billfish, and tunas. These species are key in top-down control, have high P/B and Q/B ratios, and are highly vulnerable to overfishing. They play critical roles in energy transfer from mid-trophic levels to the top of the food web.

Mid-trophic level pelagic feeders with moderate body size and high mobility; include smaller sharks, jacks, and mackerels. They serve as key intermediaries in energy transfer, with high Q/B ratios and significant biomass turnover. Often targeted by commercial fisheries.

Bottom-dwelling carnivores that feed on invertebrates and small fish; include rays, skates, and benthic fish. They occupy intermediate trophic levels, have moderate P/B ratios, and are sensitive to habitat degradation and trawling. Play key roles in benthic-pelagic coupling.

Species that graze on benthic algae, detritus, or invertebrates; include various flatfish, grunts, and small reef-associated fish. They contribute to benthic nutrient cycling and are important in energy transfer from benthic primary producers to higher trophic levels.

Small to medium-sized fish that graze on algae, detritus, and benthic invertebrates on coral and rocky reefs. High P/B ratios, key in maintaining reef health by preventing algal overgrowth. Often have complex life histories and are sensitive to habitat loss.

Small to medium-sized carnivores that occupy intermediate trophic levels on reefs; include groupers, snappers, and wrasses. They are key in controlling prey populations and maintaining reef food web structure. Often have high Q/B ratios and are vulnerable to overfishing.

Small, schooling fish that feed on zooplankton and phytoplankton; include anchovies, sardines, and small mackerels. High P/B and Q/B ratios, critical in transferring energy from primary producers to higher trophic levels. Often form the base of pelagic food webs.

Species with high economic, cultural, or subsistence value; include large pelagic predators, reef fish, and shellfish. These taxa are often overfished and require targeted management. They are separated from ecologically similar non-commercial species to support policy and fishery management.

Benthic invertebrates and small fish that consume detritus, organic matter, and microorganisms; include crustaceans, mollusks, and polychaetes. High P/B ratios, critical in nutrient recycling and benthic energy flow. Often overlooked but essential for ecosystem function.

Phytoplankton, macroalgae, seagrasses, and benthic microalgae that form the foundation of marine food webs. Low P/B ratios but high biomass turnover. Critical for carbon fixation, oxygen production, and supporting higher trophic levels.
Phytoplankton and algae forming the base of the food web.
Small fish feeding on zooplankton, crucial for energy transfer.
Species consuming algae or detritus from the seafloor.
Apex predators in open waters, feeding on fish and squid.
Predators in coral reef environments, feeding on smaller fish.
Predators hunting on or near the seafloor.
Apex predators in coastal areas, including sharks.
Schooling fish serving as prey for larger predators.
Fish living near the bottom, not necessarily benthic feeders.
Species contributing to benthic ecosystems.
High-value species targeted by fisheries.
Elasmobranchs with significant ecological roles.
Fish consuming algae or plants.
Species with varied diets, including scavenging.
Apex predators in the pelagic ecosystem, feeding on fish, squid, and other marine animals. Includes commercially important species like tuna, swordfish, and billfish.
Elasmobranchs that are top predators in coastal and offshore waters, feeding on a variety of prey including fish, crustaceans, and other marine animals.
Species that depend on coral reefs for habitat and feeding, including groupers, snappers, and other reef fish.
Small fish that inhabit the open ocean and serve as prey for larger predators. Includes species like sardines, anchovies, and herring.
Invertebrates that live on or near the seafloor, including crustaceans, mollusks, and others. Important for benthic ecosystem functioning.
Fish that primarily feed on algae and other plant material, playing a key role in regulating algal growth in their ecosystems.
Catadromous fish with unique life cycles that spend most of their lives in freshwater but migrate to the ocean to spawn. Often targeted in commercial fisheries.
Bottom-dwelling fish with a flat body shape, feeding on small invertebrates and fish. Includes species like flounder and sole.
Pelagic fish with high oil content, often targeted in commercial fisheries for their meat and as baitfish.
Crabs, shrimps, and lobsters that are important both ecologically and commercially. They play a key role in benthic ecosystems.
Squids, octopuses, and other cephalopods that are both predators and prey in marine ecosystems. Important in the transfer of energy through marine food webs.
Fish that live near the seafloor, feeding on benthic organisms. Includes species like cod and haddock.
Small fish that live near the bottom of lakes, seas, or oceans. Often serve as prey for larger predators.
Apex predators occupying pelagic and open ocean habitats, feeding on fish, squid, and other marine animals. Includes commercially important tuna, billfish, and mackerel species.
Elasmobranchs with diverse feeding behaviors, including apex predators, scavengers, and filter feeders. Includes commercially important species like hammerhead sharks and eagle rays.
Large, bottom-dwelling predators with high commercial value. Includes species like gag grouper and red grouper.
Medium to large-sized fish with diverse feeding habits, including benthic and pelagic species. Includes commercially important yellowtail snapper and red snapper.
Schooling fish that occupy pelagic and coastal habitats, serving as a critical link in the food web between phytoplankton and higher trophic levels.
Species that primarily feed on algae and plant material, playing a key role in maintaining coral reef ecosystems.
Crabs, shrimp, and lobsters with diverse ecological roles, including detritivory and predation. Many species are commercially important.
Small, schooling fish that serve as a primary food source for larger predators. Includes species like sardines and anchovies.
Species that are tightly associated with coral reefs, including damselfish, butterflyfish, and angelfish.
Predatory fish that frequent coastal and estuarine habitats, including species like barracuda and bluefish.
Species adapted to deep-water environments, often with unique ecological roles and vulnerabilities to environmental changes.
Species with high cultural or ecological significance, such as parrotfish and angelfish, which play key roles in maintaining reef health.

Top-level piscivorous predators with high trophic levels, primarily pelagic and highly mobile. These species have high body mass, slow growth, low P/B ratios, and high vulnerability to overfishing. Include apex predators such as billfish, large sharks, and tunas. Key in regulating mid-trophic fish populations and targeted by commercial and recreational fisheries.

Medium to large predatory sharks inhabiting coastal and shelf waters. Exhibit high trophic levels, low P/B ratios, and are apex or mesopredators. Often reef- or benthic-associated, with slow life histories and high vulnerability to fishing. Play critical roles in controlling fish and elasmobranch communities.

Benthic and demersal elasmobranchs with low mobility and moderate to low P/B ratios. Feed on invertebrates and small fish, occupying benthic food webs. Often associated with soft-bottom or reef habitats. Susceptible to bycatch and habitat degradation.

Large-bodied, long-lived reef predators with low P/B and Q/B ratios. Include groupers, snappers, and jacks. High trophic level, often apex or mesopredators on reefs. Highly vulnerable to overfishing due to spawning aggregations and cultural/commercial value.

Small- to medium-sized reef-associated species with moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. Include grunts, porgies, blennies, and smaller serranids. Function as mesopredators or invertivores. Important in energy transfer from invertebrates to higher trophic levels. Some are commercially harvested.

Small to medium pelagic fish with high P/B and Q/B ratios. Form schools and serve as key prey for larger predators. Include herrings, sardines, anchovies, and halfbeaks. Rapid turnover, short lifespans, and critical in transferring energy from plankton to higher trophic levels.

Bottom-associated fish with moderate to low P/B ratios. Include croakers, drums, flatfish, and grunts. Feed on benthic invertebrates and small fish. Important in benthic-pelagic coupling and targeted in commercial and recreational fisheries.

Fast-swimming, mid-trophic piscivores in coastal and offshore waters. Moderate to high P/B and Q/B ratios. Include jacks, mackerels, and barracudas. Serve as both predators and prey. Some are commercially important.

Small reef fish specializing in benthic invertebrate consumption. Moderate P/B ratios and high site fidelity. Include gobies, blennies, and small wrasses. Important in controlling invertebrate populations and nutrient cycling.

Species of high commercial and cultural value, often subject to targeted fisheries and management regulations. Ecologically similar to other reef fish but separated due to management relevance and vulnerability.

Sessile and mobile invertebrates forming the base of benthic food webs. Include crustaceans, mollusks, and echinoderms. Moderate to low P/B ratios. Serve as prey for demersal fish and rays. Some are commercially harvested.
Highly mobile invertebrates with high P/B and Q/B ratios. Include squid, octopus, and shrimp. Fast-growing, short-lived, and important prey for fish and marine mammals. Some are commercially fished.

Apex consumers with low P/B ratios and high trophic levels. Play roles in nutrient transport and top-down control. Low reproductive rates and high vulnerability to anthropogenic impacts. Include dolphins and small cetaceans.

Primary producers in coastal ecosystems. Support herbivores and provide habitat. High biomass and low turnover. Include seagrasses and macroalgae. Critical for carbon sequestration and nursery habitat.

Small pelagic animals forming the primary link between primary producers and forage fish. High P/B ratios and rapid turnover. Include copepods, jellyfish, and larval stages. Key in pelagic energy transfer.

Apex predators occupying high trophic levels with slow growth, low P/B and Q/B ratios, and high vulnerability to fishing. These large, mobile pelagic species play key roles in regulating mid-trophic predator populations and are often targeted in commercial and recreational fisheries.

Mid-to-high trophic level predators with moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. These benthic and coastal pelagic species feed on small fish and invertebrates, serving as mesopredators. They have higher productivity than large sharks but remain vulnerable to habitat degradation and bycatch.

Highly migratory apex and sub-apex predators with high metabolic demands, high Q/B ratios, and significant commercial value. These species dominate pelagic food webs and are key indicators of oceanic ecosystem health and fishing pressure.

Low trophic level, planktivorous fish with high P/B and Q/B ratios. These schooling species form the energetic link between primary producers and higher trophic levels. They are critical prey for larger fish, seabirds, and marine mammals, and are increasingly targeted by fisheries.

Mid-to-high trophic level fish that inhabit coastal and shelf waters, feeding on forage fish and invertebrates. These species have moderate P/B ratios and are important both ecologically and commercially, often serving as key links in energy transfer.

Serranids, lutjanids, and other reef-dwelling predators with moderate P/B ratios and high site fidelity. These species occupy mid-to-high trophic levels, are often protogynous hermaphrodites, and are highly vulnerable to overfishing due to aggregation behavior and commercial demand.

Benthic and demersal fish species inhabiting soft-bottom and structured habitats. These mid-trophic level predators feed on invertebrates and small fish, with moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. Many are important in commercial and recreational fisheries.

Small to medium-sized reef-associated fish with high site fidelity and diverse feeding strategies, including omnivory and invertebrate predation. These species contribute to reef trophic complexity and have moderate vulnerability to habitat loss and fishing.

Demersal fish inhabiting estuarine, nearshore, and shelf environments. These species feed on benthic invertebrates and small fish, with life histories adapted to variable salinity and temperature. Many are commercially important and sensitive to habitat degradation.

Benthic and demersal elasmobranchs with low P/B ratios, slow growth, and high vulnerability to bottom fishing. These species play important roles as benthic predators and are often bycatch in trawl and gillnet fisheries.

Sessile and mobile benthic invertebrates including crustaceans, mollusks, and echinoderms. These species serve as key prey for demersal fish and have variable P/B ratios. They are ecologically important for nutrient cycling and habitat structure.

Fast-growing, high-turnover invertebrate predators with very high P/B and Q/B ratios. These short-lived species are important prey and predators in mid-trophic levels and exhibit boom-bust population dynamics.

Top predators with low P/B ratios, long lifespans, and high trophic positions. These species have significant cultural and conservation value and influence ecosystem structure through predation and competition.

Long-lived reptiles with varied diets (herbivorous, omnivorous, jellyfish specialists). They occupy multiple trophic levels and are highly vulnerable to bycatch, habitat loss, and climate change. Protected species with high conservation priority.

Air-breathing predators that forage across pelagic and coastal zones. They link marine and terrestrial systems, feed on fish and invertebrates, and are sensitive indicators of ecosystem change and overfishing impacts.

Gelatinous zooplankton including jellyfish and ctenophores with high turnover rates and episodic blooms. These species can short-circuit energy transfer by consuming plankton and small fish larvae, impacting recruitment and food web stability.

Primary producers in shallow coastal ecosystems, providing habitat, food, and oxygen. These autotrophs support diverse communities and are sensitive to eutrophication, turbidity, and physical disturbance.
Primary producers forming the base of marine food webs. High P/B ratios and rapid turnover support higher trophic levels. Sensitive to nutrient loading, light availability, and climate variability.

Small drifting animals that consume phytoplankton and microzooplankton, transferring energy to higher trophic levels. High P/B ratios and central role in pelagic food webs make them critical for ecosystem function.

Apex predators occupying high trophic levels with slow growth, low P/B and Q/B ratios, and high vulnerability to fishing. These large, mobile pelagic species play key roles in regulating mid-trophic predator populations and are often targeted in commercial and recreational fisheries.

Mid-to-high trophic level predators with moderate P/B and Q/B ratios. These benthic and coastal pelagic species feed on small fish and invertebrates, serving as mesopredators. They have higher productivity than large sharks but remain vulnerable to habitat degradation and bycatch.

Highly migratory apex and sub-apex predators with high metabolic demands, high Q/B ratios, and moderate P/B ratios. These species are ecologically and commercially significant, dominating pelagic food webs and supporting major fisheries.

Low trophic level, planktivorous fish with high P/B and Q/B ratios. These schooling pelagic species form critical energy transfer links between primary producers and higher trophic levels. They are key prey for larger predators and support large-scale fisheries.

Mid-trophic level piscivores with moderate to high P/B and Q/B ratios. These schooling fish inhabit coastal and shelf waters, preying on forage fish and invertebrates. Many are commercially and recreationally important.

Demersal to reef-associated piscivores and invertivores with moderate P/B ratios. These species are ecologically important on reefs and highly valued in commercial and recreational fisheries, often subject to overfishing.

Large, slow-growing reef predators with low P/B ratios and high trophic positions. They serve as apex or mesopredators on reef systems and are highly vulnerable to fishing due to life history traits and spawning aggregations.

Demersal fish with omnivorous to carnivorous diets, moderate P/B ratios, and high abundance in estuarine and coastal habitats. Many are important in commercial and recreational fisheries and serve as mid-level predators.

Fast-swimming, mid-trophic level predators inhabiting coastal and pelagic zones. They have high consumption rates and play significant roles in energy transfer. Several species are commercially targeted.

Piscivorous, elongate predators with high Q/B ratios and ambush or pursuit feeding strategies. They occupy mid-to-high trophic levels in coastal and pelagic systems and are often apex predators in their niches.

Demersal, camouflaged predators with low mobility and moderate P/B ratios. They inhabit sandy and muddy substrates, feeding on benthic invertebrates and small fish, serving as important benthic-pelagic couplers.
Benthic and reef-associated omnivores and invertivores with moderate P/B ratios. They play key roles in benthic community dynamics and are commonly targeted in fisheries.

Diverse group of benthic and reef-associated fish with varied diets and life histories. They occupy mid-trophic levels and contribute to benthic energy flow. Includes species with moderate commercial value.
Benthic and pelagic elasmobranchs with low P/B ratios and high vulnerability. They feed on invertebrates and small fish, linking benthic and pelagic food webs. Often taken as bycatch.

functional_groups.group_name: Marine Bony Fish (Juvenile and Small Species)
functional_groups.description: Small-bodied, short-lived fish with high P/B ratios. These species serve as prey for larger predators and occupy lower to mid-trophic levels. Include ecologically important but non-commercial taxa.

Highly mobile invertebrates with high P/B and Q/B ratios. They are important predators and prey, exhibiting rapid growth and short lifespans. Play significant roles in energy transfer and are commercially harvested.
Decapod crustaceans including shrimp and crabs with moderate P/B ratios. They are key benthic consumers, detritivores, and prey items. Many are commercially important and sensitive to habitat change.

Filter feeders, grazers, and deposit feeders with low to moderate P/B ratios. These organisms contribute to nutrient cycling and benthic productivity. Include ecologically critical and commercially harvested species.
Small, often secretive reef fish with low mobility and moderate trophic roles. They contribute to reef biodiversity and serve as prey. Generally not targeted but ecologically significant.

Small to medium-sized fish inhabiting estuaries and coastal zones with high resilience. They occupy various trophic levels but are not typically targeted by fisheries. Important for food web stability.
Long-lived, low P/B species with high trophic positions and cultural significance. They play unique ecological roles and are protected species with high vulnerability to human impacts.
High-value reef-associated species targeted in fisheries, with distinct life histories and ecological roles. Separated due to management and economic importance.
Sedentary invertebrates including polychaetes, small mollusks, and echinoderms with low mobility and high abundance. They support benthic food webs and serve as prey for demersal fish.

functional_groups.description: Large pelagic sharks and rays that occupy top trophic levels but are not primary commercial targets. Highly mobile, long‑lived, low P/B, high Q/B, vulnerable to bycatch and habitat changes.
Mid‑size reef fishes that graze algae, scrape substrates or feed on detritus. Primarily benthic, high P/B, moderate Q/B, important for reef productivity and resilience.

Short‑lived, fast‑growing schooling fishes that dominate the mid‑water food web, linking primary production to higher trophic levels. High P/B, very high Q/B, heavily exploited by fisheries and sensitive to environmental variability.
Benthic and demersal fishes that prey on invertebrates and smaller fishes. Moderate body size, intermediate P/B and Q/B, important for energy transfer to apex predators.
Large, fast‑swimming, high‑trophic‑level fishes targeted by industrial tuna fisheries. Low P/B, high Q/B, long‑lived, vulnerable to overfishing.
Highly migratory, apex pelagic predators of high commercial value (sport and market). Low P/B, high Q/B, sensitive to habitat and bycatch.
Mid‑size pelagic predators and fast‑growing species of high market demand. Moderate‑high Q/B, important links between forage fish and apex predators.
High‑value snapper, grouper, and sea‑bass species harvested from reef and near‑shore habitats. Moderate‑large body size, relatively low P/B, high Q/B, heavily managed.
Key benthic invertebrate resources with high economic importance. Short life cycles, high P/B, high Q/B, sensitive to habitat degradation and overharvest.

Diverse benthic organisms (echinoderms, holothurians, small crustaceans, gelatinous zooplankton) that provide ecosystem services such as bioturbation, nutrient recycling, and prey for higher trophic levels. Generally high P/B, low Q/B, low direct fishery pressure.
Highly mobile, long‑lived vertebrates occupying top trophic levels, with low productivity and high sensitivity to ecosystem changes and human impacts.

functional_groups.description: Includes organisms that primarily occupy the pelagic zone and feed on phytoplankton or other small particles.  Important for energy transfer from primary producers to higher trophic levels.  Often have high biomass and contribute significantly to the marine food web.  Vulnerable to ocean acidification and pollution.

Large, active predators that occupy the pelagic zone.  Important for regulating populations of smaller fish and maintaining ecosystem balance.  Often have long life spans and are vulnerable to overfishing.

Includes a diverse group of predators that inhabit coral reefs.  Often have specialized diets and are important for maintaining reef ecosystem health.  Many are vulnerable to habitat loss and overfishing.
Includes a variety of invertebrates that live on the seafloor in deep water.  Often have specialized adaptations to survive in the extreme conditions of the deep sea.  Data availability is limited.
Includes fish species that are harvested for human consumption.  Often highly valued and subject to intense fishing pressure.  Important for food security and economic livelihoods.
Fish species that inhabit coral reefs and nearshore waters.  Important for reef ecosystem function and often have complex life histories.  Vulnerable to habitat degradation and overfishing.

functional_groups.description: Includes primary producers (phytoplankton) and filter-feeding organisms that occupy the base of the pelagic food web.  Characterized by small size, high biomass, and significant role in energy transfer.  Vulnerable to ocean acidification and pollution.

Diverse group of fish inhabiting coral reefs and rocky coastal areas.  Includes predatory and herbivorous species, often with bright coloration and complex social behaviors.  Important for reef ecosystem function.

Includes predatory fish and invertebrates inhabiting deep-sea environments or benthic habitats.  Often adapted to low light conditions and high pressure.  Important for regulating populations of other deep-sea organisms.
Large, open-ocean predators that occupy the top of the food web.  Important for regulating populations of smaller fish and marine mammals.  Vulnerable to overfishing.
Small fish and invertebrates that inhabit coral reefs and rocky areas.  Often serve as prey for larger predators.  Important for reef ecosystem function.
